headline: Disruptions: Next Step for Technology Is Becoming the Background
abstract: From the printing press to the Google glasses, the earliest lumbering efforts in technology morph over time into streamlined, unnoticed tools of daily life, writes Nick Bilton.

headline: Where Have You Parked Your Short-Term Savings?
abstract: This week’s Your Money column looks at where savers with short-term savings goals can park their cash.

headline: Peugeot in Talks to Sell Logistics Business
abstract: A deal would help PSA Peugeot Citroën of France endure declining sales in Europe while bolstering Russian Railways’ links between Europe and Asia.

headline: Tips for Living on a College Student Budget
abstract: The author, who was raised in India, offers money management tips for international students who plan to study in the United States.

headline: New Fraud Inquiry as JPMorgan’s Loss Mounts
abstract: Amid a swirl of questions about a multibillion-dollar trading loss, JPMorgan said Friday that it would be forced to restate its first-quarter results, indicating that its traders may have intentionally been trying to conceal the extent of the red ink on the disastrous credit bet.

headline: India Lets in Wal-Mart, With Conditions
abstract: The government opens up India’s retail sector, but asks for sizable investment.

headline: Q&A: Checking Android App Permissions
abstract: Android apps list their permissions on both the device and on the Web.

headline: Business Day Live: Drought Disrupts Everyday Tasks in Rural Midwest
abstract: For farmers, drought becomes a way of life. | Americans near retirement suffer big income losses. | James B. Stewart discusses Mitt Romney’s foreign tax credit.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Twitter Founders’ Trifecta and Thoughts on the iPad Mini
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Thursday’s selection includes a third online publishing tool from the founders of Twitter and Blogger and musings on the possible design of the iPad Mini.

headline: A Glimpse of Ramadan From the Kashmir Valley
abstract: The observance of Ramadan by locals in Srinagar, summer capital of Jammu and Kashmir State.

headline: Image of the Day: August 1
abstract: Anti-corruption activist Anna Hazare’s hunger strike enters fourth day.

headline: Contract Dispute Delays Start of ‘Modern Family’ Production
abstract: The leading cast members of ABC’s hit comedy failed to show for the reading of the new season’s first script, while also filing suit in Los Angeles seeking to invalidate their contracts.

headline: The Brute Force Computing Revolution
abstract: The centuries-old scientific and engineering idea of progress through observing, modeling, testing and modifying is under attack. Now it is better to collect and examine lots of data, looking for patterns, and follow up on the most promising. The latest example: Autodesk says designers should generate a thousand product versions.

headline: From Bihar, a New Approach to Flood Control
abstract: Under Nitish Kumar, the state is rethinking the way it controls flooding.

headline: Once an Asset, Diamond’s American Flair Became a Liability for Barclays
abstract: The rise and fall of Robert Diamond, the chief executive of Barclays who resigned on Tuesday in the midst of a rate-manipulation scandal, closely tracks the City of London’s own complicated history with Wall Street’s risky ways.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
abstract: Top magazine and long-form articles this week.

headline: Yahoo Chief’s Challenge? Corner Office, New Baby
abstract: By tackling a difficult corporate job while pregnant, Marissa Mayer, the new chief of Yahoo, is challenging the idea that senior executive ambitions and a woman’s family life don’t mix.

headline: Hedge Fund Manager Found Guilty of Insider Trading
abstract: After less than a day of deliberations, a federal jury found Doug Whitman of Whitman Capital in Menlo Park, Calif., guilty of earning about $1 million in illegal profits trading technology stocks, including Google and Polycom.

headline: Indian Art Exhibition Makes a Rare Stop in China
abstract: “Indian Highway,” the largest ever Indian art show in China.

headline: Former Clinton Adviser Joins Microsoft
abstract: Mark Penn, a former strategic adviser to Bill and Hillary Clinton, will now work for a new boss: Steve Ballmer, the chief executive of Microsoft. The company said that Mr. Penn, 58, will become a corporate vice president at the company for strategic and special projects, leading a “small interdisciplinary team.”

headline: A Peeping Tom and Toxic Pigs: China’s Olympic Headaches
abstract: Elite Chinese athletes in their final preparations for the Olympics, which open on Friday, are now focusing on special training routines while eliminating distractions. One distraction that the women swimmers didn’t need was a peeping Tom in their locker room — along with the politics over a visit by the Dalai Lama and Chinese pork dangerously loaded with steroids.

headline: Q&A: Replacing a Sealed MacBook Pro Battery
abstract: Replacing the battery in a newer Mac laptop is not as easy as it used to be.

headline: App Smart Extra: More Music-Teaching Apps
abstract: There is no shortage of fun apps for teaching children music.

headline: China Assails U.S. ‘Arrogance’ in Report on Religious Freedom
abstract: The United States has issued its annual report on religious freedom around the world, taking particular aim at repression and crackdowns in China, North Korea and Myanmar. China shot back that the report was “full of prejudice, arrogance and ignorance.”

headline: 3Taps Files Antitrust Action Against Craigslist
abstract: On Monday, 3Taps, a company that collects public data and organizes it for developers to use, filed an antitrust lawsuit against Craigslist, accusing the company of engaging in anticompetitive business practices.

headline: Ban Ki-moon’s Tehran Trip: Damned if He Does …
abstract: Ban Ki-moon has sometimes appeared more “secretary” than “general” in his leadership of the United Nations. Does his decision to travel to a conference in Tehran mark a new-found independence or is it just a gesture to the U.N.’s nonaligned members? And can he use the opportunity to scale back the tension over Iran’s nuclear policy?

headline: Rising Tension — and Stakes — in Japan-China Island Dispute
abstract: After Japan’s purchase this week of three disputed islands from a Japanese family, attacks in China on Japan and Japanese and a disruption in private relations. And things are likely to get worse.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Fears of Fires Cancel Some Fireworks Displays
abstract: Fears of fires cancel some fireworks displays, the bristle brush as a barbecue hazard, a family reunion in the fjords of Norway and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Speaking Urdu or Bengali a Cause for Police Suspicion in NYC
abstract: Officer in New York City’s police department said he is focusing on Urdu and Bengali speakers in hunt for terrorists.

headline: In Assam, the Brahmaputra River Remains Uncontrollable
abstract: River embankments have failed to stem flooding, and experts seek a new approach.

headline: Friday Reading: To Brief the Teacher, or  Hold Your Tongue?
abstract: When to brief the teacher about your child and when to hold your tongue, be cautious with free software, a chance to paint where Georgia O’Keeffe did and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: The Risks of Hosting a Successful Olympics
abstract: London’s wildly successful Games may have others thinking that if they can host a successful global event their country’s image will soar. Not true. Ask South Africa. And Brazil?

headline: BlackRock Fined $15.2 Million by British Regulator
abstract: The Financial Services Authority of Britain has fined BlackRock for failing to follow rules governing the protection of its clients’ money.

headline: Daily Report: Relic of an Era, Revitalized for Tech Start-Ups
abstract: Chicago’s River North’s transformation is extending to one of the neighborhood’s most storied — and decidedly low-tech — commercial addresses. The Merchandise Mart, a Depression-era behemoth of limestone, concrete and steel that has long been synonymous with fabric bolts and furniture, is becoming a destination for the city’s digital set.

headline: If Little Else, Banker’s Trial May Show Wall St. Foolishness
abstract: The civil trial of a former Citigroup banker may not turn out to be the great exposé of the financial crisis, but it will almost certainly show Wall Street’s wrongheadedness.

headline: NBC Says Nearly 220 Million Watched the Olympics
abstract: That total over 17 days made the Games the most watched entertainment or sports event ever on American television.

headline: Digital Notes: Spotify Offers a Bit More Information About Its Users
abstract: The streaming-music service on Tuesday said it had 15 million monthly users around the world, with four million paid subscribers. Since January, it has added a million paid subscribers.

headline: Netanyahu’s Bomb Explodes on the Internet
abstract: Israel’s prime minister provoked an avalanche of mixed reactions by using a cartoon prop to underline what he sees as the nuclear threat posed by Iran. Was it appropriate for a speech to the U.N., or should he have stuck to his script?

headline: Anna Hazare’s Movement Turns Political
abstract: The anti-corruption activist and his team say India needs an alternative to its current government.

headline: It’s Not Clear What Valet Offers, But It Wants $200 for It
abstract: Valet, a new travel venture, charges $200 a year for membership — but it’s not clear what the service offers.

headline: Did Yelp and TripAdvisor Push Google to Compete?
abstract: By buying Frommer’s travel guides, Google has set competitors like Yelp and TripAdvisor on edge. But, as an analyst points out, Google is publishing its own reviews because its first attempts at collecting reviews also angered competitors.

headline: Google Snaps Up Wildfire
abstract: Google has agreed to acquire Wildfire, which helps brands manage their social campaigns across sites like Facebook, Twitter and Pinterest. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Microsoft Admits Risk in Tablet Plans
abstract: In an annual report, Microsoft finally conceded something that has been rather obvious to anyone with a rudimentary understanding of the personal computer industry. Microsoft acknowledges that its Surface tablet computers could weaken support for Windows among Microsoft’s partners in the PC business.

headline: Ahold Weighs Sale of Stake in ICA of Sweden
abstract: The Dutch retailer Ahold says it is considering options for its 60 percent stake in the Swedish supermarket chain ICA, including selling its holding.

headline: NBC’s ‘Tonight Show’ Cuts Staff, and Jay Leno Takes a Pay Cut
abstract: The late night talk show is cutting costs by laying off staff and reducing the pay of its host, Jay Leno.

headline: Wall Street Scandals Fill Lawyers’ Pockets
abstract: The white-collar bar is thriving with cases like the collapse of MF Global and the manipulation of the London interbank offered rate.

headline: A Long Lens on Afghanistan’s Wars
abstract: Robert Nickelsberg has been making images of Afghanistan’s various conflicts since 1988, and in a new project he puts the fighting into historical context.

headline: The Long-Term Value of Internet Companies
abstract: Bill George, a Harvard business professor, argues that investors should be focusing on Facebook’s future instead of wondering why it had lost so much of its I.P.O. value.

headline: Aiming for Colleges That Are Generous With Merit Aid
abstract: A chart helps compare hundreds of colleges that offer merit aid to incoming freshmen.

headline: Months of Transition Ahead for NBC News Online
abstract: While switching Web addresses from MSNBC.com to NBCNews.com was easy, it will take months for Microsoft and NBC to fully dissolve the deal that formed MSNBC.com as a 50-50 joint venture in the mid-1990s.

headline: A YouTube Introduction to U.S. Colleges, by Just Clicking Play
abstract: More American colleges and universities are using YouTube to reach prospective students, allowing students opportunities to improve their college searches and strengthen their applications.

headline: How Much Does the Fed’s Plan Really Help Main Street?
abstract: In theory, the Fed’s latest bond purchases should drive down borrowing costs for companies and consumers, making them more likely to take out loans to buy goods and services and thus stimulate the economy. But many rates, like those for credit card loans, remain stubbornly high.

headline: Kevin Costner Plans Book Project
abstract: The actor and director will produce an illustrated adventure series that will first be released in book format and later as films.

headline: Delhi Strays Thrive on Affection From a Few
abstract: A menace for a large population, dogs on Delhi streets are regularly fed by generous dog lovers.

headline: Small Cells and the Future of Wireless
abstract: Small cells could play a big part in helping to deal with the demand for wireless spectrum. But what exactly are they? In a report presented this month, a presidential panel laid out a proposal for how the country could get more out of its radio spectrum, like embracing small cells and other technologies that would use the radio waves more efficiently.

headline: One on One: Ricky Gervais, Comedian Turned App Developer
abstract: Ricky Gervais will unveil a new app on Wednesday. The app, Just Sayin’, lets people record two-way voice conversations and broadcast them to Twitter and Facebook. Bits caught up with the comedian to try to understand who would possibly need such a thing.

headline: Average A.T.M. Surcharge Reaches New High
abstract: The average A.T.M. surcharge rose to a new high of $2.50, an analysis from Bankrate.com finds.

headline: Why Credit Scores Aren’t Always What They Seem
abstract: Consumers who buy access to their credit score may get one that differs from the one lenders use.

headline: Image of the Day: July 11
abstract: Commuters at a crowded railway station in Mumbai, Maharashtra, on World Population Day.

headline: In West Bengal, Cashless Microfinance Opens Doors for Women
abstract: Women receive what they need to ply a trade, including basic education, before qualifying for a loan.

headline: SAIC Plans Two-Way Split
abstract: The Science Applications International Corporation said on Thursday that it planned to cleave itself into two publicly traded companies, becoming the latest in a string of corporate breakups.

headline: Jobs Report Preview
abstract: The Labor Department releases its June employment report on Friday. The median forecast is that job growth ticked up slightly to 90,000 and that the unemployment rate stayed at 8.2 percent.

headline: Debate Over Chinese Swimmer Turns Testy in Asia
abstract: Suspicions voiced by a leading international swim coach about the remarkable Olympic performance of a young Chinese swimmer has started a huge debate. Did she perhaps dope, or did her breakout swim come through her physical gifts and a decade of hard training? In Asia, some believe the debate is fueled by the West’s jealousy over a rising China, and perhaps even smacks of racism.

headline: Riding High on ‘Hatfield and McCoys,’ A&E Gives Dubuc a New Deal
abstract: The executive has turned the network into a ratings winner with shows like “Pawn Stars” and the miniseries “The Hatfield and McCoys.”

headline: Chinese Purchase of AMC Theaters Is Said to Win Approval of Regulators
abstract: Dalian Wanda Group said its acquisition was on track to close in August.

headline: DirecTV-Viacom Dispute May Affect Access for 20 Million Customers
abstract: The dispute is the latest in a series of fights over the fees distributors pay to programmers for bundles of channels, a model that is increasingly being challenged.

headline: Why A.I.G. May Not Be Able to Avoid the Volcker Rule
abstract: Robert H. Benmosche, A.I.G.’s chief executive, told CNBC that the insurance company was planning to sell a small bank it owned in an effort to shield the insurer from curbs on proprietary trading. But it is not as simple as that.

headline: Its First Graduates on the Job, Venture for America Looks for Fresh Recruits
abstract: The organization is gearing up to recruit a fresh batch of 100 fellows and exploring a handful of cities for expansion in 2013. The long-term objective is to create 100,000 jobs by 2025.

headline: On a Night Crowded With Hits, ‘Big Bang’ and ‘Grey’s Anatomy’ Stand Out
abstract: The CBS comedy had the highest ratings for Thursday night, while ABC’s hospital drama had strong results despite fears that interest might be fading. A new ABC drama, “Last Resort,” has a promising debut.

headline: Justice Dept. Approves, With Changes, Verizon Wireless Spectrum Purchase
abstract: The deal to pay $3.6 billion for wireless airwaves owned by Time Warner Cable, Comcast, Cox Communications and Bright House Networks still needs F.C.C. approval.

abstract: The government opens up India’s retail sector, but asks for sizable investment.

abstract: For farmers, drought becomes a way of life. | Americans near retirement suffer big income losses. | James B. Stewart discusses Mitt Romney’s foreign tax credit.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Twitter Founders’ Trifecta and Thoughts on the iPad Mini
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Thursday’s selection includes a third online publishing tool from the founders of Twitter and Blogger and musings on the possible design of the iPad Mini.

headline: A Glimpse of Ramadan From the Kashmir Valley
abstract: The observance of Ramadan by locals in Srinagar, summer capital of Jammu and Kashmir State.

headline: JetBlue Sign Joins the New York Skyline
abstract: The airline plans to unveil on Wednesday evening a sign atop its headquarters in Long Island City. The sign depicts the airline’s logo in 15-foot letters.

headline: R.B.S. Insurance Unit to Cut 900 Jobs
abstract: The Direct Line Insurance Group, owned by Royal Bank of Scotland, has announced plans to cut about 900 jobs as it looks to reduce costs ahead of an initial public offering.

headline: Putting the France Back Into the Tour
abstract: In the past half-decade, local fans lining the race route on Bastille Day have had little to cheer about except the day off from work: the last French Tour winner was in 2005.

headline: Olympic Politics: What Does It Mean for Boris?
abstract: Big sport can sometimes get tangled up with big politics, and the just-ended Olympic Games in London was no exception.

headline: Image of the Day: September 20
abstract: A devotee offering milk to a snake during a Hindu festival.

headline: Swift Rescue in U.S. Provides Lessons for Europe
abstract: The necessary steps to fix a financial crisis in the United States were painful and unpopular, according to the writer, who was the head of the Obama administration’s financial crisis response team. But in Europe, the consequences of a delayed or inadequate response are far worse.

headline: Telecom Services Blocked to Curb Protests in Kashmir
abstract: Internet and cellphone service suspended by state authorities in Kashmir for several hours on Friday.

headline: CNN Looks for a Boost From HBO Shows
abstract: As Time Warner attempts to reinvigorate its 24-hour cable news channel, the company has pushed for CNN to incorporate HBO’s sports and documentaries into its lineup of news programs.

headline: A Phone That Can Take a Dunking
abstract: The Kyocera Hydro, available without a contract through Boost Mobile, is waterproof for up to 30 minutes in water about three feet deep with no additional protective case.

headline: A Photo App That Pays You
abstract: Usually you have to pay for an app, but Foap is an app that proposes to pay you. Foap puts your iPhone photos up for sale online.

headline: This Week in Small Business: An Elevator on the Moon
abstract: Plus: Assessing the candidates, dreams of retirement, and what’s your B.Y.O.D. policy?

headline: Save the Tiger, Ban the Tourists
abstract: India’s Supreme Court bans tourists from large parts of the country’s dozens of tiger reserves.

headline: Daily Report: Consumer Sites Broaden Mission to Include Businesses
abstract: The clear line between Internet companies that cater to consumers and those that serve businesses is beginning to blur, reports Nick Wingfield on Monday in The New York Times.

headline: E-Mail Birthday Intrigue
abstract: Who invented e-mail? There’s a story about that.

headline: France and Britain Weigh the Price of Nuclear Deterrence
abstract: Britain and France are second-ranking powers that “punch above their weight,” in part because they have nuclear weapons. But some would like to cut the cost of this ticket to the top table without jeopardizing their world power status at the United Nations.

headline: Who Is to Blame for Facebook’s I.P.O.? A Mix of Responses
abstract: The DealBook column on Tuesday, which pinned the blame of Facebook’s mess of an initial public offering on its chief financial officer, David Ebersman, has provoked a wide range of reactions among the online financial commentariat.

headline: Portraits of China’s People (and Their Possessions)
abstract: Huang Qingjun photographs Chinese people in front of their homes, surrounded by their belongings. His images are intimate portraits of lives in a country getting rich fast, but one where vast numbers of people still struggle.

headline: Tip of the Week: Add a World Clock to Google Calendar
abstract: The World Clock add-on for Google Calendar lets you keep track of international time zones when making plans.

headline: Reformers Do Win Elections in India
abstract: New data dispels a long-standing myth about pro-growth politics.

headline: A Pitch for a Company That Helps Students Find Their Passions
abstract: Marc Busko, a professional speaker, has already been booked to speak before 2,800 students — although it is unclear whether that is for pay.

headline: Business Day Live: China’s $15 Billion Oil Deal
abstract: Why China is investing in North American energy companies. | The former special inspector general of TARP critiques bailout policies. | The economic fallout from declining school enrollment.

headline: Rajesh Khanna, Romantic Star
abstract: Mr. Khanna preceded the action-hero genre, and choose difficult romantic roles

headline: A Conversation With: Chef Vikas Khanna
abstract: The Michelin-starred chef’s recipe for sol kadi, his ambitious plan of writing an encyclopedia of Indian cooking, and his upcoming book “Return to the Rivers.”

headline: How Not to Pitch Your Business in Social Media
abstract: It’s amazing how bad some pitches can be. Don’t make these mistakes.

headline: Pitching an Organic Cigarette for Hipsters
abstract: Hestia Tobacco positions itself as the first truly independent organic cigarette company, and there are a number of strong elements to the pitch.

headline: A Tax Shelter Mitt Romney Could Love
abstract: Gov. Mitt Romney’s 2011 tax return highlights the use of a tax planning technique that may have allowed him to avoid Medicare tax liability on up to $2 million of income derived from his past employment at Bain Capital.

headline: Trulia Prices I.P.O. at $17 a Share, Above Expected Range
abstract: Trulia priced its initial stock offering at $17 a share on Wednesday, surpassing expectations as the real estate search site raised $102 million.

headline: Blaming Obama for George W. Bush’s Policies
abstract: Mitt Romney’s economic team ignores the record in blaming President Obama for ills created by George W. Bush’s policies, particularly his tax cuts, an economist writes.

headline: Image of the Day: July 18
abstract: Fans pay their last tributes to Bollywood actor Rajesh Khanna.

headline: Business Day Live: Facebook and Apple
abstract: The Times’s daily business show looks at whether Facebook has lost credibility with Wall Street and the remarkable transformation of Apple.

headline: Power Restored to Most of North India
abstract: The reason for Monday’s massive power outage is still being investigated.

headline: Introducing the Latin Euro
abstract: The tide in Europe is running against Germany and toward a weaker European Central Bank, two economists write.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
abstract: Best of long-form journalism this week.

headline: Federal Judge Grudgingly Approves Morgan Stanley Price-Fixing Case
abstract: A federal judge on Tuesday approved a $4.8 million settlement between the Justice Department and Morgan Stanley over accusations of price fixing in the electricity market, even as he said that the settlement amount was too low.

headline: A Box of Crayons for the iPad
abstract: DigiTools, a set of physical coloring tools for the iPad, is an effort by Crayola to bring the crayon’s waxlike simplicity to touch-screen coloring,

headline: Arming for the Syrian War: Do Soaring Prices Predict Escalating Conflict?
abstract: Inside the arms market for Syrian rebels, where demand is intense and prices are high.

headline: Daily Report: Facebook Needs a Story
abstract: The challenge for Facebook, which is worth just over half of what it was three months ago, is to convince Wall Street that it has a real plan for making money.

headline: Business Day Live: Criminal Networks Behind E-mail Spam
abstract: Wall Street gets bearish on itself. | Striking a blow at the criminal networks behind e-mail spam. | Children finding substitutes for Nickelodeon. | Brian Stelter on the 2012 Emmy nominations.

headline: Authenticity and Ethnicity
abstract: Why do Indian, African and Arab writers who are longtime legal citizens of Britain or the United States still identify themselves as Indian, African or Arab? And is there really such a thing as an authentic Indian, Arab or African novel?

headline: Image of the Day: August 17
abstract: A festival dedicated to Hindu snake goddess “Manasa” celebrated in Kolkata, West Bengal.

headline: Dead, Again, in Ghana
abstract: The untimely death of John Atta Mills, a darling of the U.S., will test the democratic institutions of one of West Africa’s pillars of stability.

headline: Europe Aims to Make Rate Manipulation a Criminal Offense
abstract: The European Commission announced plans on Wednesday to make the manipulation of benchmark interest rates a criminal offense, while saying British authorities did not do enough to stop rate-rigging.

headline: Daily Report: Facebook’s First Earnings Report Disappoints Investors
abstract: Facebook’ investors unloaded their shares after the company’s first earnings report in the public markets, reports Somini Sengupta on Friday in The New York Times, sending the stock price to a record low.

headline: Q&A: Resetting a Lost Twitter Password
abstract: When you lose the passwords connected to your Twitter account, you still have a few options for recovery.

headline: Disruptions: Looking Beyond Silicon Valley’s Bubble
abstract: Within the bubble of Silicon Valley, everyday conversations can touch on private jets and billion-dollar deals. But if you look past the ostentation, truly magical work is taking place.

headline: Note to Self: Double-Check Those Electric Bills
abstract: A Connecticut woman was reimbursed for thousands of dollars she unknowingly paid to power two streetlights.

headline: Wisconsin Attack Exposes the Angry Music of ‘Hatecore’
abstract: White power music, a powerful tool for keeping the supremacist movement alive.

headline: A New Boss For NBC News, MSNBC and CNBC
abstract: All of the company’s news divisions will now report to Patricia Fili-Krushel, a veteran of ABC and Time Warner

headline: A Limit to Gains From Genetically Engineered Cotton
abstract: The genetically altered crops have higher yields, but insects may evolve to erase the gain.

headline: Headphones That Quiet Trains and Riders — But Not at the Same Time
abstract: Do noise-canceling headphones try to do too much to too many sounds? Audio-Technica would say yes, and is selling its ATH-ANC9 QuietPoint active noise-canceling headphones with three different modes intended to improve noise-canceling in different conditions.

headline: After Huge Loss, JPMorgan Rearranges Top Officials
abstract: Matthew Zames and Frank Bisignano were promoted to co-chief operating officers of the bank, while Jes Staley moved from being chief executive of the corporate and investment bank to chairman.

headline: Tuesday Reading: States Stiffen Driving Laws for Teenagers
abstract: Many states stiffen teen driving laws, male binge-eating steps out of the shadows, few midsize luxury sedans ace crash tests and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Transocean to Sell 38 Oil Rigs for About $1 Billion
abstract: Transocean, the world’s largest offshore drilling contractor, has agreed to sell 38 rigs in so-called shallow water to a private equity consortium.

headline: Your Experience With Small-Time Private Equity Investments
abstract: What the new breed of investors betting smaller amounts of money in private companies need to know to succeed.

headline: Comcast to Sell Back Its Stake in A&E for $3 Billion
abstract: Comcast said on Tuesday that its NBC Universal subsidiary had agreed to sell back its 15.8 percent stake in A&E Television Networks. The deal values A&E at about $19 billion.

headline: A Padlock People Might Want to Steal
abstract: The Master Lock 1500eDBX DialSpeed has a light-up electronic touch pad face instead of a spinning dial, unlocking with a combination of up, down, left and right clicks.

headline: RIM Innovates and Then Waits as Apple Moves Ahead
abstract: RIM announced a bunch of innovative features for its next smartphone last May. The only problem is, the iPhone has them now and the BlackBerry won’t arrive until sometime next year.

headline: An Interview: The Taliban’s Long View
abstract: The Taliban are prepared to accept less than full control over Afghanistan after American troops leave, but are still fighting to command a major role in the country’s future, according to an interview with a senior Taliban commander in which he lays out the movement’s long-term political views.

headline: F.T.C. Still Expects to Resolve Google Antitrust Inquiry by Year’s End
abstract: The chairman of the Federal Trade Commissions said on Wednesday that investigators expected to meet a deadline they disclosed earlier this year.

headline: XOXO: A Festival of Indie Internet Creativity
abstract: The XOXO Festival in Portland, Ore., over the weekend brought 400 people together to discuss the many ways that the Internet is helping to “creatively disrupt” traditional businesses and industries. Here are a few of the highlights.

abstract: The observance of Ramadan by locals in Srinagar, summer capital of Jammu and Kashmir State.

headline: As Silicon Valley Cheers Yahoo Chief, Wall Street’s Reaction Is Muted
abstract: Across Silicon Valley, venture capitalists, entrepreneurs and former colleagues broadcast their enthusiasm for Marissa Mayer, the new chief executive of Yahoo, even as investor reaction was tepid.

headline: Q&A: Posting Flickr Picture Links to Twitter
abstract: Linking your social media accounts to each other can make photo sharing easier.

headline: Don’t Let the Original Price Haunt Your Decision to Sell
abstract: Whether it’s Facebook stock or our homes, our tendency to let the price we paid for assets become anchors in our minds can be harmful.

headline: France Passes a Tougher Sexual Harassment Law
abstract: Does the news leave you thinking, ‘It’s about time!” Or concerned that France could be headed the way of U.S.-style political correctness?

headline: This Subway Series Is About Commerce, Not Baseball
abstract: Subway is introducing “4 to 9ers,” a comedy series appearing on hulu.com. The show centers on young employees of the restaurant, who work there from 4 to 9 p.m. after they finish high school for the day.

headline: The iPhone 5: My First Impressions
abstract: Bigger screen, longer battery life, more sophisticated camera, better sound. Overall, Apple seems to have put its focus on the important things you want in an app phone.

headline: General Mills Adds Social Media to Product Pitch
abstract: General Mills is turning to social media like Pinterest to help introduce a new product it calls Fiber One Chewy bars.

headline: India’s Electrical Grid: Did Someone Fall Asleep at the Controls?
abstract: India is short of power capacity, but that doesn’t explain this week’s blackouts.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: In Relocating of War Gear, a Larger Force Strategy Emerges
abstract: With the war in Iraq ended and Afghanistan beginning to wind down, the Army is faced with two big questions. Where do you move your heavy equipment? And why?

headline: ESPN Targets American Cricket Fans
abstract: Cricket’s appeal is strong and growing, sports network said.

headline: What the Barclays Settlement Means for Other Banks
abstract: For the other banks in the Libor investigation, the Barclays settlement provides a template for the type of cooperation the Justice Department expects, and the range of monetary penalties they may have to pay.

headline: Lie More, as a Business Model
abstract: The scandal over interest rate manipulation by Barclays staff members shows just how deeply the culture of dishonesty runs in major banks, an economist writes.

headline: Indian Conglomerate Buys New York’s Plaza Hotel
abstract: The acquisition is the latest in a string of Indian purchases of foreign hotels.

headline: Yelp Surges After Lockup Expires
abstract: Shares rose 22.51 percent, its largest one-day gain since the company went public in March.

headline: A Stand That Isn’t Pretty, but Practical
abstract: The Pocket-eAzl is an aluminum and rubber stand that folds to a small size but can be adjusted to hold most readers, pads and phones upright.

headline: Love and Marriage in a Traditional Climate
abstract: Instead of hiding behind her notepad, a reporter opens up to her subjects to better understand the context behind a Muslim Brotherhood premarital counseling workshop.

headline: After MF Global, Another Brokerage Firm Collapses With $200 Million Missing
abstract: Months after the failure of MF Global, regulators are scrambling to deal with the collapse of PFGBest, which is missing more than $200 million in customer money.

headline: Pulled From Dish Network, AMC Will Stream ‘Breaking Bad’ for Viewers
abstract: The channel is upping the ante in its dispute with Dish by sending its viewers online for at least one episode of the popular show.

headline: It’s Official: Facebook Closes Its Acquisition of Instagram
abstract: Five months after the deal was first announced, the Federal Trade Commission cleared Facebook to complete its acquisition of Instagram, the popular mobile photo-sharing application.

headline: Women’s Magazines Lead Overall Decline in Newsstand Sales

headline: Monday Reading: How to Avoid Getting Fleeced by Travel Fees
abstract: Avoiding fees when you travel, Medicare bills rise as records turn electronic, questioning the tip on a split restaurant bill and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Canadians Ask Why Design of $100 Bill Replaced Asian Woman With White One
abstract: Focus groups that evaluated the new bank note before it went into circulation raised questions about why a woman on the back of the bill was Asian, according to reports. She was replaced by a “neutral”-looking woman.

headline: At 90, Artist Abdul Aziz Raiba Earns New Fans
abstract: A contemporary of some of the biggest names in modern art, Mr. Raiba is gaining recognition late in life.

headline: Simmering Chinese Anger at Japan Is Now on the Boil
abstract: Street protests and bellicose talk in China are increasing tensions between Beijing and Tokyo in their dispute over some barren, rocky islets. Chinese protesters smashed Japanese cars and attacked sushi restaurants. A Chinese general wants to mine the islands and use them for bombing practice.

headline: Aliens With Dance Moves and the Midas Touch
abstract: Review of Shirish Kunder’s ‘Joker.’

headline: Barbara Marcus to Lead Random House Children’s Books
abstract: Ms. Marcus, who is known for her time at Scholastic and her acquisition of the Harry Potter books, will succeed Chip Gibson.

headline: When Fairness Opinions Are Used Outside of Mergers
abstract: The growth of fairness opinions, which are used in merger deals to provide a gauge of a company’s worth, in nontraditional situations is an emerging trend that deserves scrutiny, the author writes.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: A round-up of news from across India.

headline: Hollywood Struggles for Proper Response to Shooting
abstract: Warner Brothers canceled a premiere in Paris and appearances by cast members, but was still studying the implications of the shooting on “The Dark Knight Rises,” which took in $30.6 million in 12:01 a.m. shows on Friday.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Milestone for Twitter Spambot, and Andreessen Horowitz
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday’s selection includes a pictorial analysis of the smartphone industry, a look at a powerhouse venture capitalism firm and a star spambot reaches 100,000 followers on Twitter.

headline: Founders of Diaspora, Intended as the Anti-Facebook, Move On
abstract: Two summers ago, a quartet of students at New York University started an ambitious project called Diaspora that was intended to be an open alternative to Facebook. But since then the project seems to have petered out. The founders said on Monday that they would be turning it over to its users.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: A round-up of news from across India.

headline: Google Uses Its Home Page to Push Nexus 7 Tablet
abstract: Google’s stark white home page is the most-viewed Web site on the Internet, and Google is taking advantage of that by advertising its Nexus 7 tablet there. Though it is not the first time Google has advertised its products on the home page, the ad comes at a crucial time for the Android tablet.

headline: Disney to Asian Pirates: Knock It Off
abstract: When some of Walt Disney’s most celebrated characters showed up on North Korean television the other day, one could almost hear Uncle Walt screaming down oaths from the afterlife.

headline: Middle East Journal: Pitching Tables in Dubai
abstract: The trip was intended to be an introduction. Getting a chance to work on a real project was a bonus.

abstract: Eric E. Schmidt, the executive chairman of Google, used a fireside chat at the Allen & Company conference to show off some of the company’s new gadgets.

abstract: The Gujarat chief minister spoke in a rare interview to an weekly Urdu newspaper.

headline: A Tutoring Company in Search of a Tag Line
abstract: Alexandra Mayzler recently asked the group for advice on one of her latest ideas for her company, Thinking Caps Tutoring. Settling on a tag line that sounds good and differentiates the company has been difficult.

headline: Did the U.S. ‘Lose’ Ho Chi Minh to Communism?
abstract: The historical question continues to nag: Was Ho Chi Minh a communist from his very beginnings, or was he a nationalist freedom fighter whom the United States “lost” to communism? A new pre-history of the Vietnam War offers some clues.

headline: Stiff Sentence for Former Gujarat Minister
abstract: Confidant of Narendra Modi gets 28-year prison term for her role in 2002 riots.

headline: Spicy Corn Pakoras Give Buttered Ears a Rest
abstract: The marriage of American corn and Indian chickpea flour yields an appetizing snack.

headline: Occupy Hong Kong’s Fate Now in a Court’s Hands
abstract: The Occupy movement, whose members have been encamped outside HSBC’s headquarters in Hong Kong for nine months, on Monday fended off a first legal bid by HSBC seeking to evict the protesters.

headline: Image of the Day: September 5
abstract: Remembering Mother Teresa on her death anniversary in Kolkata, West Bengal.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Kimmel, Fox and ‘Call Me Maybe’ Make Waves
abstract: Also, Macy’s gets into the high school musical business, and “Fifty Shades of Grey” has fans in the corporate suite.

headline: Alibaba Is Said to Be Close to Raising $8 Billion
abstract: Some American Internet companies may be unpopular with investors these days, but a Chinese one is finding plenty of takers.

headline: Heineken Wins Asian Brewer for $4.6 Billion
abstract: Shareholders of Singapore’s Fraser & Neave, the parent of Asia Pacific Breweries, voted on Friday to approve the sale of the beer making unit to Heineken after a two-month battle with a Thai billionaire.

abstract: At the annual meeting of Research in Motion in Canada, the BlackBerry maker faced questions from unhappy shareholders.

abstract: Intel agreed on Monday to buy a 15 percent stake in ASML, a Dutch semiconductor equipment maker, in an investment that may total as much as $4.1 billion.

abstract: The rich in America — many of whom backed Barack Obama in 2008 — have turned against the president this year, despite the fact that banks received the biggest government bailout of all.

abstract: Top magazine and long-form articles this week.

headline: In Northwest Corner of India, the Work of Centuries
abstract: The craftsmen of Gujarat struggle to keep their art alive.

abstract: Lawmakers wonder why the regulator failed to rein in banks that manipulated benchmark interest rates.

abstract: The anonymous Navy SEAL member who wrote the book remained anonymous for less than 24 hours.

abstract: The observance of Ramadan by locals in Srinagar, summer capital of Jammu and Kashmir State.

abstract: The second massive power outage in two days in India.

headline: Weill Calls for Splitting Up Big Banks
abstract: They were words no one ever expected Sanford I. Weill to utter. “What we should probably do,” said the man who helped usher in the age of the financial supermarket, “is go and split up investment banking from banking.”

headline: In Canada, the Impact of America’s New Patent Law Is Seen
abstract: The United States passed new patent legislation last fall and key provisions are scheduled to take effect early next year. New research analyzing the experience in Canada, after it made a similar legal change, suggests that small inventors will be hurt. Patents awarded to individual inventors dropped by 15 percent after the legislative change in Canada.

headline: China Sends Two to Labor Camp for Marching in Hong Kong
abstract: Two people from mainland China are reported to have been sent to a labor camp for protesting in Hong Kong, even as the United States says “the human rights situation in China continues to deteriorate.”

headline: Best Buy Names Hospitality Executive as New Chief
abstract: Best Buy has hired the chief executive of the hospitality company Carlson, Hubert Joly, as its new leader, after saying that an olive branch that the company had offered to its discontented founder had been rejected.

headline: Employers That Forbid You From Telling Others What You Make
abstract: Some thoughts about companies that contractually forbid employees from telling anyone how much money they earn.

headline: Geithner Holds His Own on Triathlon Front
abstract: Timothy F. Geithner is well known as being something of a fitness nut. And on Sunday, the Treasury secretary showed off his athletic abilities with a highly respectable finish of a triathlon held in the nation’s capital.

headline: Putting the S.B.A. Into Perspective
abstract: If the Small Business Administration makes progress, that’s great — but the problems are bigger than the S.B.A.

abstract: WPIX, the New York City affiliate of the CW network, is off the air in homes serviced by Cablevision as the two sides reached an impasse in talks over retransmission fees.

abstract: It’s a good thing that Asian countries are at the London Games: They’ve provided nearly all the colorful moments to an Olympics that has amounted, so far, to about fifty shades of gray.

abstract: Protests in New Delhi over violent clashes in Assam between Bodos and Muslims.

headline: Rented Computers Captured Customers Having Sex, F.T.C. Says
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission agreed to a settlement with seven companies and a Pennsylvania-based software maker, which had distributed software on rental computers that spied on more than 420,000 customers, secretly capturing “webcam pictures of children, partially undressed individuals, and intimate activities at home.”

headline: Bud Light Steps Up Its N.F.L. Sponsorship Efforts
abstract: Anheuser-Busch is introducing a campaign for its Bud Light brand that declares this to be the “Year of the Fan.”

headline: My Thoughts on E-Book Pricing? Let Me Draw You a Picture
abstract: Bob Kohn, an outspoken critic of the Department of Justice’s settlement with three publishers over e-book pricing, said he hoped to be more economical with his words by using pictures as well.

headline: Again, Wrangling Over Surveillance in the Cybersecurity Bill

headline: Video: A New RIM?
abstract: Research in Motion promises to become lean and mean. Do analysts believe it?

headline: Online, Colorado Suspect Seems a Phantom
abstract: A common name and an unusual silence make Colorado shooting suspect a phantom — so far — in the digital age.

headline: India’s Congress Party Leads in Donations
abstract: The party controlled by the Gandhi family draws more than twice the donations of its biggest rival.

headline: Other Ways to Look at G.D.P. and What It Tells Us
abstract: Just how strong the economy is, and what benefits economic growth, are matters of continuing debate among economic theorists, an economist writes.

abstract: Standard Chartered, which has thrived so far during Europe’s debt crisis, faces costly fines in an investigation of its financial dealings with Iran.

abstract: The Urban Elite Laptop Backpack from Pelican Products has a built-in shockproof, waterproof case that can accommodate a 15” laptop, or a 17” MacBook.

abstract: Dynegy files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, the latest step to restructure the ailing energy company and settle with creditors who hold more than $2.5 billion in claims over one of its subsidiaries.

headline: GE Capital Sells Property Lending Unit for $2.51 Billion
abstract: EverBank Financial Corporation, a bank based in Florida that went public last month, has agreed to acquire Business Property Lending, a unit of GE Capital, for $2.51 billion in cash.

headline: South Asian Designers Make Their Mark at Fashion Week
abstract: From ornate beading and threadwork to deep-hued tones, their designs were well-received.

headline: Taiwan’s Progress on Health Care

headline: Man Group Announces More Cost Cuts as Assets Decline
abstract: Man Group, the world’s largest publicly traded hedge fund manager, is planning an additional $100 million in cost cuts by the end of next year in a bid to stem the continuing decline in its assets under management.

headline: The Khan Academy Goes to Camp, and It’s All Offline
abstract: The Khan Academy starts a summer camp that is about getting your hands dirty, not staring at the screen.

headline: Usher and Shakira to Join ‘The Voice’ Next Season
abstract: They will substitute for Christina Aguilera and Cee Lo Green next spring. It is evidence, along with the news of new big-name judges for “American Idol,” that stars are eager to hitch themselves to TV talent shows.

headline: In Spain, It’s Not Just the Economy

abstract: Preventing costly smartphone bills after an overseas trip, an online education site expands its menu of schools and courses, making parents part of the gay wedding day and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

abstract: Free ATM Inc. is expanding its advertising-supported cash machines to the new Barclays Center.

abstract: From downtown San Francisco to Palo Alto, Calif., companies like American Express and General Motors are opening offices and investing millions of dollars in local start-ups, reports Evelyn M. Rusli in Tuesday’s New York Times. But the push into Silicon Valley comes even as the broader venture capital industry goes through a shaky time.

headline: UBS Hires Grafstein as Co-Head of M.&A. in the Americas
abstract: UBS has hired Laurence Grafstein, a veteran deal maker, as a co-head of mergers and acquisitions in the Americas, the Swiss bank announced on Tuesday in an internal memorandum reviewed by DealBook.

headline: Bank of America Settles Suit Over Merrill for $2.43 Billion
abstract: Bank of America announced on Friday that it would pay $2.43 billion to settle a class action lawsuit related to its acquisition of Merrill Lynch.

headline: Filling Regis’s Shoes … Michael Strahan
abstract: Tuesday was the first day of “Live With Kelly and Michael.”

headline: What Marissa Mayer Means for Silicon Valley Women
abstract: Marissa Mayer’s two new roles — chief executive and mother — mean that Silicon Valley, the heart of American innovation, could become the place where a more progressive attitude toward women and work takes root. After all, it is difficult to imagine other, more conservative industries, like finance or law, hiring a chief executive in her third trimester.

abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

abstract: Companies turn to social media sites as market research departments. | A rare dynasty in the world of hedge funds.

abstract: Dell, looking to expand beyond its business of selling personal computers, announced on Monday that it would buy Quest Software as it expands its data services business.

headline: As Apple’s Maps Stumbles, AOL’s MapQuest Flourishes
abstract: Apple’s map application debacle has been a boon for an unlikely suspect: MapQuest. The map company, owned by AOL, seemed to have been eclipsed in the era of in-car GPS and smartphones, but it is experiencing a resurgence.

headline: XOXO Fest, An Experimental Tech Conference, Gets Underway
abstract: The XOXO Fest in Portland, Ore., this weekend raised money using Kickstarter. Its methods are a theme for the music festival/start-up conference.

headline: Former Goldman Programmer Is Arrested Again
abstract: The Manhattan district attorney has charged Sergey Aleynikov, the former Goldman Sachs programmer, with state crimes related to his downloading of computer code from his onetime employer.

abstract: One Marine finds new mobility after receiving a graft from the bladder of a pig that helped regrow some of the muscle he lost in a bomb blast in Afghanistan.

headline: Daily Report: Germans Reopen Facebook Privacy Inquiry
abstract: German data protection officials have reopened an investigation into Facebook’s use of facial recognition software. It could lead to fines against the social network giant.

abstract: JPMorgan Chase is being investigated over whether it manipulated power markets in California and the Midwest, according to a filing from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission.

abstract: Mitt Romney has promised to create 12 million jobs in the next presidential term. Is that aim bold, overly optimistic — or pretty much what some economists already expect?

abstract: The two will join Mariah Carey and Randy Jackson for a level of musical firepower that reflects both the show’s continuing importance to the music business and the need to freshen its appeal with viewers.

abstract: The aerospace giant EADS, which manufactures Airbus passenger aircraft, says it is in merger talks with its British rival, BAE Systems.

headline: Friday Reading: West Nile Cases on the Rise
abstract: West Nile cases on the rise, what can you learn in a 15-minute doctor visit, help for an ailing router and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: HSBC Reveals Problems With Internal Controls
abstract: HSBC, the largest financial institution in Europe, has become the latest British bank to reveal major internal-control problems, saying that senior officials would apologize to U.S. lawmakers next week for not cracking down soon enough on money-laundering activities in America.

headline: Big-Data Investing Gets Its Own Supergroup
abstract: The Data Collective, a new fund specializing in Big Data investments, claims to have 35 equity partners with lots of experience in the field, to find deals, build companies and work on exits.

headline: How to Make a Dead Cat Bounce on Twitter
abstract: A number of lessons learned about sharing stories on Twitter, Facebook, Reddit and other social Web sites. To report, write, edit and publish, we can add a new fundamental task for reporters: share.

headline: A Fashion Week Homage to Michael Jackson’s Thriller
abstract: Fashion week is well under way in London and one of the exciting highlights so far was Philip Treacy’s Sunday show where the milliner was inspired, literally, by Michael Jackson’s stage wardrobe.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: Where Is David Pogue’s iPhone?
abstract: David Pogue’s iPhone was stolen. After he let the world know on Twitter, a search ensued. Here’s his story.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: A Twitter Video Series, and Craigslist vs. PadMapper
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday’s selection includes what it would take to develop a new smartphone, a state’s plan to register voters using Facebook and how the government invented the Internet.

headline: JPMorgan’s Former Leader Makes a Case for Big Banks
abstract: William B. Harrison Jr., a primary architect of the modern-day JPMorgan Chase, writes in an op-ed in The Times that the breakup of big banks would not prevent risky behaviors.

headline: Daily Report: Online Dating Services Go Retro
abstract: Online dating services have long promised to help people find a mate by using statistical science to predict personal chemistry. But some of the biggest services are now adding a retro twist, Jenna Wortham reports in Wednesday’s New York Times.

headline: Release of Book on Bin Laden Raid Is Moved Up a Week
abstract: “No Easy Day,” written by a member of the Navy SEALs team that killed Osama Bin Laden, will now go on sale Sept. 4. The publisher, Dutton, says its planned print run was increased to 575,000.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Charges in Phone Hacking, and Super-Secret Surveillance
abstract: Also, concerns about “microtargeted” political ads, and a coming Obama fund-raiser will have a tie-in to “The Wire.”

headline: Olympics Spectacle Stirs Great British Pride. What Did You Think?
abstract: It was quirky. It was funny. And it was very, very British. There was widespread praise for London 2012’s opening ceremony that showcased “a nation secure in its own post-empire identity, whatever that actually is.”

headline: Bo Xilai’s Son Defends His ‘Upright’ Father
abstract: Bo Guagua, the son of the disgraced former Communist Party leader Bo Xilai, has posted a statement online about the “upright” father whom he knew to be “devoted to duty.” The elder Bo, expelled last Friday from the party, is due to stand trial on criminal charges; his wife, Gu Kailai, was convicted of murder in August.

headline: Politico Reporter Removed From Akin Coverage After Tweets
abstract: Dave Catanese tweeted that there should be more discussion about Representative Todd Akin’s comments about abortion and what he called “legitimate” rape.

headline: U.S. Spends Too Much, Taxes Too Little. Neither Candidate Has Offered a Real Solution
abstract: The right says Washington spends too much. The left says it taxes too little. Historical and global comparisons suggest both are right, although to different degrees.

headline: Jodi Picoult Changes Publishers
abstract: The bestselling author, who has written 19 novels, is moving from Atria to Ballantine Bantam Dell for her next book deal, covering three books.

headline: ‘The Dark Knight Rises’ Takes in $88 Million Overseas
abstract: The film also had $160 million in North American box office sales over the weekend, showing that the deadly shooting last Friday at a theater in Colorado had dampened the enthusiasm of moviegoers only slightly.

headline: Can Square Remain Hip?
abstract: Excitement is building around the payments company, which just struck a deal with Starbucks. But it may be too early to anoint Square as the firm that will lead us into a cashless society.

headline: MF Global Trustees Differ Over Amount Customers Will be Repaid
abstract: James W. Giddens, the trustee for customers, says a $1.6 billion gap remains, but the trustee for creditors, Louis Freeh, says customers will be made whole.

headline: A Tool for Those Who Fall Behind on Student Debt
abstract: An online guide may help you evaluate options if you are behind on student loan payments.

headline: Unlock Your Phone With a Look
abstract: The latest version of the Android operating system simplifies the process with a feature called “face unlock,” that unlocks the phone when you, and only you, look at it.

headline: Drilling Down: Jared Bernstein Says Small Businesses Are Not Overtaxed
abstract: An economist argues that the best thing the president and Congress could do for small businesses right now is to provide them with economically healthier customers.

headline: Ways to Make Life Joyful
abstract: Bucks readers offer their own alternatives to an indulgence that’s mainly for the wealthy — yachting.

headline: This Week in Small Business: Health Care Fantasies
abstract: Plus: the 25 biggest product flops, Google’s bid to control the future, and “no-brainer” businesses anyone can start.

headline: Image of the Day: August 21
abstract: A flock of pigeons flying past a boy in Mumbai.

headline: A Law Firm Where Money Seemed Secondary
abstract: At Cravath, Swaine & Moore, associates were paid based on seniority, with no bonuses and no resentments.

headline: Morning Take-Out
abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: How Bollywood’s Views on Pakistan Evolved
abstract: Overt and covert representations of the Indian-Pakistani relations in Indian cinema over the decades.

headline: Among Moguls, Affection for Obama Wanes
abstract: While the president still has plenty of fans at Allen & Company’s annual gathering of media and technology magnates, some who were once ardent supporters of the president last time are ready to switch their vote to Mitt Romney.

headline: It’s Not Too Soon to Think About Crowdfunding
abstract: If you take these steps, you may have a crowd in place when equity crowdfunding gets final approval.

headline: Sports Illustrated to Start Monthly TV Show With NBC
abstract: Starting July 24, the magazine will join with NBC to present a new sports program, with many of the stories featuring tie-ins to articles in the magazine.

headline: Manchester United Sets Price Range for I.P.O. at $16 to $20 a Share
abstract: Manchester United is moving forward with its initial public offering, disclosing on Monday that it is seeking $16 to $20 a share in its return to the public stock markets.

headline: Children Who Sell Themselves
abstract: Extreme poverty forces some Indian children to offer themselves as child labor.

headline: A Dangerous Gateway to Mount Everest
abstract: Nepal has been home to numerous airplane crashes in the past decade.

headline: Under Investigation, and Doing the Investigation
abstract: In dealing with corporate misconduct, the government may be leaning too much on the law firms hired by the companies under investigation.

headline: A Quest for Six-Packs, Inspired by Bollywood
abstract: As leading men flaunt beefcake on-screen, fitness centers have quickly multiplied in India.

headline: U.S. Special Operations Commander Cautions Against Exploiting ‘Celebrity’ Status
abstract: Adm. William McRaven had in mind the recent news that a former member of the Navy SEALs team that killed Bin Laden had written a book, and also an effort by former Special Operations members to accuse President Obama of leaking information to enhance his reputation.

headline: S.E.C. Pays Out First Whistle-Blower Reward
abstract: Federal securities regulators say they have handed out the first reward under a new whistle-blower program, paying nearly $50,000 to an unnamed person who helped the agency shut down an investment fraud.

headline: The Man Who Stayed Behind in China Comes Into Focus
abstract: The first American to join the Chinese Communist Party turns 91 next month, and a new documentary describes how a kid from Charleston, South Carolina, ended up in a mountain cave playing gin rummy with Mao Zedong.

headline: Swap Market, Like Libor, Is Vulnerable to Manipulation
abstract: A proper market would want an organization that was impartial, regulated, transparent and open to appeal, but with credit default swaps, there is no such luck.

headline: Box and Dropbox Come of Age in Cloud Computing
abstract: Two online data storage companies, Box and Dropbox, have found business models that let each other thrive, and may have given them a way to take on Amazon.

headline: Will Windows Phones Replace BlackBerrys as Bargaining Chip?
abstract: A research report suggests more bad news for Research in Motion. The cellphone carriers could use Windows 8, not BlackBerry, to counterbalance the power of Android and Apple.

headline: Documentary Takes a Business View of Street Drug Trade
abstract: “How to Make Money Selling Drugs,” a new documentary film, takes a businesslike look at the world of street drugs, offering professional advice to and assessing the prospects of low-level dealers.

headline: National Ad Campaign for Citibank Reward Program to Feature Alicia Keys
abstract: The Private Pass program offers cardholders early access to tickets for sporting events and concerts, but in its latest version, there are also small group events with celebrities like Ms. Keys.

headline: A Global Steel Giant Scales Back
abstract: Lakshmi Mittal’s company contracts as demand cools.

headline: Best Buy’s Tough Earnings May Lift Schulze’s Hopes a Little
abstract: Best Buy’s worse-than-expected second-quarter earnings may provide ballast for the company’s founder and his hope to buy it back. But the results also raise the question of whether the struggling retailer has time to turn itself around, in public or in private.

headline: The 14 Potential Causes of the Income Slump
abstract: Why has median household income endured its worst 12-year stretch since the Great Depression? Experts and readers respond to some of the potential causes.

headline: Business Day Live: The New High-Tech Dating Technique? Meet in a Bar
abstract: The challenges that await Best Buy’s new chief executive. | Online dating services go retro. | How the music industry’s hit-making process is changing.

headline: Assam’s Floods Take Toll on India’s Rhinos
abstract: More than a dozen rare one-horned rhinos have been killed by flooding.

headline: As the Wars Ebb, Considering Security at Home
abstract: More than a decade after the 9/11 attacks, what sacrifices are Americans still willing to make in the name of national security?

headline: College, Still Worth It
abstract: The more income you earn, the more likely you are to have gone to college.

abstract: Best of long-form journalism this week.

abstract: This week’s Your Money column looks at where savers with short-term savings goals can park their cash.

abstract: A deal would help PSA Peugeot Citroën of France endure declining sales in Europe while bolstering Russian Railways’ links between Europe and Asia.

headline: Tips for Living on a College Student Budget
abstract: The author, who was raised in India, offers money management tips for international students who plan to study in the United States.

abstract: The government opens up India’s retail sector, but asks for sizable investment.

headline: Q&A: Checking Android App Permissions
abstract: Android apps list their permissions on both the device and on the Web.

headline: A Glimpse of Ramadan From the Kashmir Valley
abstract: The observance of Ramadan by locals in Srinagar, summer capital of Jammu and Kashmir State.

headline: Jefferies Raises Questions About Schulze’s Best Buy Holdings
abstract: As part of his audacious takeover proposal for Best Buy, Richard Schulze said that he would contribute about $1 billion of his holdings into a leveraged buyout offer. But an analyst at the Jefferies Group wondered why the company founder wasn’t rolling in more of his shares.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Smartphone Satellites and Inheriting E-Books and iTunes
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Monday’s selection includes Lindsay Lohan’s $2,145 Blackberry, how books and records may differ from their digital counterpartsd when it comes to inheritance, and people who listen to police scanners and send the results out via Twitter.

headline: Connecting the Dots After Cyberattack on Saudi Aramco
abstract: Publicly released details of a cyberattack on Saudi Aramco, the world’s largest oil producer, appeared to confirm reports that critical data on three-quarters of the company’s PCs was replaced with an image of a burning American flag.

headline: Best Buy to Open Books for Founder
abstract: Best Buy said on Monday that it had finally agreed to let its founder, Richard Schulze, take a closer look at its financial statements to help him firm up his potential takeover proposal for the electronics retailer.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Dial-up Staying Alive, and Zuckerberg Humor
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Friday’s selection includes Facebook’s lack of forecasts for the next quarter or year, a new watch linked to the iPhone and a slowdown in the decline of AOL’s dial-up business.

headline: A Conversation With: Anand Sharma
abstract: India’s minister of commerce and industry explains recent reforms.

headline: In UBS Convictions, Parallels to the Libor Investigation
abstract: A case against the three former UBS executives who were convicted last week has a number of interesting parallels to the Libor investigation, and can provide the framework for cases that might emerge.

headline: Exodus to India’s Northeast Continues for a Third Day
abstract: Indian leaders appealed for calm as natives of northeastern India continued their mass exodus from southern cities, fearing retaliation for communal violence in the northeastern state of Assam.

headline: Are the Big Banks Keeping Their Commitment to Small Businesses?
abstract: Last September, 13 of the nation’s largest banks promised to increase their lending to small businesses by $20 billion over three years. How’s that going?

headline: Friday Reading: Who’s Watching Mom?
abstract: Who’s watching Mom, New Yorkers face unabated indoor noise, Ford recalls 2013 EcoBoost Escapes and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: More Credit Cards Without Foreign Transaction Fees
abstract: Cardratings.com identifies three dozen credit cards without foreign transaction fees.

headline: Credit Suisse Names DeNunzio as Global Chairman of M.&A.
abstract: Credit Suisse on Wednesday named David DeNunzio, one of its veteran deal makers, as the global chairman of its mergers and acquisitions group. The news follows the departure of Steven Koch to serve as a deputy mayor of Chicago.

headline: How to Make Your Lost Phone Findable
abstract: There are apps that help you find your lost phone. They may not work perfectly, but using them increases the odds of success.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Google Oceans, and Promises ‘The Jetsons’ Made Us
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday’s selection includes a report that says few sales can be traced to social media, a cheaper way to charge an iPhone 5 and an argument that Apple must change its strategy when it comes to television.

headline: Wildfire Damage Is Generally Covered by Homeowners’ Policies
abstract: Homeowners’ insurance generally covers losses from wildfire though some insurers may require people living in high-risk places to take steps to cut the likelihood of fire damage, like moving propane tanks 30 feet from the home.

headline: ‘Afghanistan’ Not Among Buzzwords at G.O.P. Convention
abstract: On Thursday, when Mitt Romney accepted the nomination, the only person to mention the Afghan war was Clint Eastwood, who failed to sync with Mr. Romney’s own remarks on the American withdrawal.

headline: Image of the Day: September 25
abstract: Women working in the unorganized sector demand social security benefits from the government.

headline: Universal Closes on EMI Deal, Becoming, by Far, Biggest of Remaining Big Three
abstract: The sale, which was first struck last November, was completed on Friday. Even after Universal sells off a third of EMI’s assets, as required by regulators, it will have a market share of 36 percent.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Thursday, Sept. 27
abstract: News, fashion, arts and sports in today’s International Herald Tribune.

headline: One on One: Reggie Fils-Aime, President of Nintendo of America
abstract: Reggie Fils-Aime, president and chief operating officer of Nintendo of America, says the game maker’s new Wii U, a game console that can be operated with a touch-screen controller, and Nintendo TV, its new online video service, show that the company is becoming more of a full-fledged entertainment business.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Isaac Crashes G.O.P. Convention, and Whither ‘Nightline’?
abstract: Also, The Guardian and a conservative commentator part ways, and two member of Pussy Riot are said to have fled Russia.

headline: Why Does Wall Street Always Win?
abstract: A new book by a Washington insider sheds light on the might of Wall Street and its ability to thwart all attempts to contain its power and alter its practices, an economist writes.

abstract: Highlights from the DealBook newsletter.

headline: Plot Twist in the A.I.G. Bailout:  It Actually Worked
abstract: As distasteful as the effort was, it should be clear by now that the rescue of the American International Group — often called a backdoor bailout of Wall Street — was a success.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
abstract: Top magazine and long-form articles this week.

headline: Daily Report: Hostels for the Hopeful Young in Silicon Valley
abstract: In The New York Times on Friday, Brian X. Chen reports on “hacker hostels,” apartments in the San Francisco Bay Area that offer short- or long-term stays for aspiring tech entrepreneurs on the bottom rung of the Silicon Valley ladder, those who haven’t yet achieved Facebook-level riches. These establishments put a twist on the long tradition of communal housing for tech types by turning it into a commercial enterprise.

headline: Heineken Faces Challenge Over Asian Brewer
abstract: Thai Beverage has increased its stake in Fraser & Neave, the Singapore conglomerate that has agreed to sell its rights in Asia Pacific Breweries to Heineken for around $4.1 billion.

headline: Business Day Live: Viewers Don’t Want Conventional
abstract: David Carr on why political conventions should embrace the ethos of reality TV. | Learning how to cut the digital lifeline.

headline: Your Worst Financial Mistake
abstract: Two-thirds of Americans admit to making “really bad” financial decisions.

headline: Image of the Day: September 7
abstract: Women protest a dam project in Madhya Pradesh by standing in neck deep water for almost two weeks.

headline: The Death of a ‘Butterfly’ in Kabul
abstract: A little girl died in a suicide bombing on the streets of Kabul, and with her, so too died the last shred of innocence she brought to one woman.

headline: A Conversation With: Tribal Expert Virginius Xaxa
abstract: India’s hundreds of tribal populations have “become uprooted from their own land and forests,” expert says.

headline: Micron to Acquire Elpida Memory in Deal Valued at $2.5 Billion
abstract: Micron Technology has agreed to buy Elpida Memory, which filed for bankruptcy earlier this year, for $754 million in cash and $1.76 billion in installments to cover debt.

headline: Using Twitter to Promote the Fall TV Season
abstract: To showcase its new fall season, the CW network will use Twitter to preview the season premiere of the program “Emily Owens, M.D.”

headline: The Winning Record of Prosecutors on Insider Trading
abstract: The United States attorney’s office for the Southern District of New York has an 8-0 winning record in insider trading cases that have gone to trial under its wide-ranging investigation. Defendants may view that record as a sign that cooperation is their best option.

headline: The Sale of Nicira, Cheaper Clouds and Troubled Cisco
abstract: VMWare is buying Nicira, which makes software-based computer networking systems, for $1.26 billion, over 25 times what had been invested in the company. The deal vastly extends VMWare’s reach, and creates new problems for its close partner, Cisco Systems, on a day when Cisco said it was cutting 2 percent of its work force.

headline: In ‘Bhopal: A Silent Picture,’ Artist Recalls the 1984 Disaster
abstract: An experimental art exhibit about the Union Carbide plant leak uses a shipping container, photographs and sound effects to recall the tragedy.

headline: John Phelan, N.Y.S.E. Chief Who Ushered In New Technology, Is Dead at 81
abstract: John J. Phelan Jr., a former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange who introduced computer technology to the Big Board in the 1980s, died on Saturday. He was 81.

headline: Business Day Live: Olympics Clean-Up
abstract: As it seeks to reinvent Motorola, Google cuts jobs. | Britain cleans up and tallies its tab after the Olympics.

headline: Under the British, Satire and Critical Cartooning Thrived in India
abstract: A sharp contrast to the government’s reaction to cartoon critiques today.

headline: Moral Policing, India’s Ugly New ‘Reality TV’
abstract: Are television stations harassing women and inciting mob anger to boost ratings?

headline: Business Day Live: Geithner’s Barclays Concerns
abstract: A prescient warning that big banks could manipulate interest rates. | Inside a massive e-mail security breach. | When this ship hits port, the journey has just begun for its cargo of new cars.

headline: Does It Pay to Become a Teacher?
abstract: The average primary school teacher in the United States earns about 67 percent of the salary of an average college-educated worker in the United States. The comparable figure for all of the developed world is 82 percent.

headline: Poking Fun at Apple’s New Maps
abstract: Now that plenty of iPhone customers have had a chance to use the new Apple maps for a few days, the reactions have been strong, and often sarcastic.

headline: U.S. Consumer Watchdog to Oversee Credit Bureaus
abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau will examine and make rules covering about 30 credit reporting companies, including the big three — Equifax, Experian and TransUnion.

headline: Karmazin Tones Down Language on Sirius Takeover
abstract: The company’s quarterly earnings conference call on Tuesday gave its chief executive a chance to moderate his comments about a takeover of the company by Liberty Media, which is run by John Malone.

headline: Year-Over-Year Home Values Rise for First Time in Five Years, Zillow Says
abstract: Median home values are expected to increase by 1 percent in the coming year, Zillow, the real-estate Web site, says.

headline: Daily Report: Apple’s Feud With Google Is Now on the iPhone Screen
abstract: Google and Apple have been foes for a while. But last week their battles spilled onto the screens of consumers’ smartphones.

headline: Syria’s Dark Horses, With Lathes: Makeshift Arms Production in Aleppo Governorate, Part I
abstract: The development of local arms-producing industries in Syria provides a good indicator of the stubborn determination and evolving organization of the fighting groups trying to unseat President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Examining the Ubiquity of Private Equity
abstract: A Q.&A. with Jason Kelly, author of “The New Tycoons: Inside the Trillion Dollar Private Equity Industry That Owns Everything.”

headline: Virus Seeking Bank Data Is Tied to Attack on Iran
abstract: A security firm said it had discovered what it believed was the fourth state-sponsored computer virus to surface in the Middle East in the last three years, one apparently aimed at collecting information from computers in Lebanon. It appears to have been written by the same programmers who designed Flame, which was found to be spying on computers in Iran.

headline: Las Vegas and the Prince Harry Effect
abstract: British media said Prince Harry was headed for a dressing-down from his father this weekend over his Las Vegas antics. The Nevada resort city was meanwhile looking forward to an unexpected boost.

headline: Protests Stir Fears for Arab Spring
abstract: Continuing anti-American protests, following the death of the U.S. ambassador to Libya and three colleagues, have raised fears in the Arab world about the future of democratization and relations with the West.

headline: As Attitudes Shift on P.T.S.D, Media Slow to Remove Stigma
abstract: Some in the media continue to perpetuate a stigma linking military service to mental illness and violence, a veteran of the Air Force argues.

headline: Firestone Shows ‘Drive’ in New Ad Campaign
abstract: Firestone plans to begin running a campaign on Sunday that urges car owners to “Drive a Firestone.”

headline: Image of the Day: September 6
abstract: Environmentally friendly rickshaws distributed to women from poor families in New Delhi.

headline: In Effort to Curb Money Market Funds, a Plan B Is Considered
abstract: Government regulators are considering invoking powers that were granted by the Dodd-Frank law to improve oversight of the money market fund industry.

abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. headline: At Peregrine Financial, Signs of Trouble Seemingly Missed for Years
abstract: Regulators may have missed red flags for years at Peregrine Financial Group, whose founder, Russell Wassendorf, a prominent futures industry executive, was arrested Friday on charges of making false statements to regulators.

headline: Apple on Its iOS 6 Maps: Things Can Only Get Better
abstract: After Apple’s maps service in its new iOS 6 operating system was greeted with widespread criticism, the company said Thursday saying that it was working hard to improve the technology.

abstract: The observance of Ramadan by locals in Srinagar, summer capital of Jammu and Kashmir State.
