abstract: Personal trainers to Bollywood stars have become stars in their own right, complete with high fees.

headline: Spotify Is Said to Profit From Its Subscribers, but Lose More Luring Them
abstract: According to a report by Enders Analysis, a British research firm, the challenge for Spotify is how to add paying customers without giving away too much of what the report calls “expensive free music.”

headline: Qatar Imperils Big Merger of Commodity Companies
abstract: The wealthy emirate, which is a shareholder in the big mining company Xstrata, may hold out for a higher price in a proposed merger with Glencore International, which trades in raw materials.

abstract: Reports that Kohlberg Kravis Roberts may ride in to help bolster the Japanese chip maker Renesas Electronics have given its shares a big boost.

headline: Evercore Profit Rises 19% on Advisory Gains
abstract: Evercore Partners’ profit rose 19 percent in the second quarter, as the investment bank’s core advisory business posted strong results.

abstract: The ING Group said on Wednesday that it would sell its Canadian unit to Scotiabank for about $3.1 billion in cash, as the Dutch bank continues to sell assets to pay for its government bailout.

headline: Santander’s Mexican Unit Sells U.S. Shares at $12.18 in Dual Listing
abstract: The Mexican arm of Banco Santander priced the U.S. portion of its initial public offering at about $12.18 on Tuesday, according to a person briefed on the matter, within its expected price range as the lender held one of the biggest stock sales ever by a Mexican company.

abstract: A small group of “big trouble” lawyers repeatedly show up on the dockets of major corporate scandals across the decades, both as government prosecutors and as defense counsel.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Anti-Muslim Trailer’s Murky Past, and Casting Nina Simone
abstract: Also, the iPhone 5 arrives, and President Obama’s re-election campaign is increasingly reliant on some big names rounding up large contributions.

headline: Where ‘Socialized Medicine’ Has a U.S. Foothold
abstract: Opponents of a greater government role in health care seem to overlook the system for military veterans, which has all the hallmarks of a socialized medicine program, an economist writes.

abstract: Disillusionment with the stock market and shareholder activism are contributing to the drop in the number of Americans investing in equities and to the decline of the publicly traded corporation, an economist writes.

headline: Company Denies Role in Recently Uncovered Spyware
abstract: An executive at Gamma Group, a British company that sells surveillance technologies, denied that a spyware program running on servers in 11 countries was developed by his company. Security researchers say the evidence suggests otherwise.

headline: Google Plans to Buy Frommer’s Travel Guides
abstract: The Internet giant is buying the travel guide maker from John Wiley & Sons to expand its local and travel search results.

headline: Week in Review: Earnings Point to a Smaller Wall Street

abstract: A campaign for a nonprofit group, the Lung Cancer Alliance, carries the theme “No one deserves to die.”

abstract: Many say the small but burgeoning Palestinian tech sector is on the verge of big things, aided by the lack of impediments to movement that Israel imposes in the name of security.

headline: The New Tug of War Over Medicaid
abstract: The new health care law calls for expansion of Medicaid, but American voters may well rebel against the program over time.

headline: 11 Found Slain, Including Ranger, at Park in Kazakhstan
abstract: Members of the ranger’s family and some of his co-workers were among the victims found stabbed to death in Ile-Alatau State National Park.

abstract: From the printing press to the Google glasses, the earliest lumbering efforts in technology morph over time into streamlined, unnoticed tools of daily life, writes Nick Bilton.

abstract: This week’s Your Money column looks at where savers with short-term savings goals can park their cash.

abstract: A deal would help PSA Peugeot Citroën of France endure declining sales in Europe while bolstering Russian Railways’ links between Europe and Asia.

abstract: The author, who was raised in India, offers money management tips for international students who plan to study in the United States.

abstract: Amid a swirl of questions about a multibillion-dollar trading loss, JPMorgan said Friday that it would be forced to restate its first-quarter results, indicating that its traders may have intentionally been trying to conceal the extent of the red ink on the disastrous credit bet.

headline: India Lets in Wal-Mart, With Conditions
abstract: The government opens up India’s retail sector, but asks for sizable investment.

abstract: Android apps list their permissions on both the device and on the Web.

abstract: For farmers, drought becomes a way of life. | Americans near retirement suffer big income losses. | James B. Stewart discusses Mitt Romney’s foreign tax credit.

abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Thursday’s selection includes a third online publishing tool from the founders of Twitter and Blogger and musings on the possible design of the iPad Mini.

headline: A Glimpse of Ramadan From the Kashmir Valley
abstract: The observance of Ramadan by locals in Srinagar, summer capital of Jammu and Kashmir State.

headline: Unruly Proceedings in Trial of Russian Punk Group
abstract: Amid unruly proceedings inside and outside the courtroom, prosecutors rested their case against the band, accused of hooliganism over a protest at Moscow’s main cathedral.

headline: How Plan to Help City Pay Pensions Backfired
abstract: A bond sale that was intended to help Stockton, Calif., reduce a shortfall in pension money wound up making the problem worse.

headline: Smart Cars Get a Connection Test in Michigan
abstract: A Wi-Fi-like technology to warn drivers of hazards is being tested in a yearlong program in Michigan.

headline: Trying to Protect a Reef With an Otherworldly Diversion
abstract: Nearly 500 statues in an underwater museum in Cancún, Mexico, serve as part of a conservation effort of the Mesoamerican Reef, the second-largest barrier reef system in the world.

headline: Justice and ‘a Ray of Hope’ After 2002 India Riots
abstract: Evidence based on cellphone records has led to hundreds of convictions in the Gujarat State riots, and India has yet to experience another large-scale paroxysm of sectarian violence.

headline: Off-Script Scramble for Power in a Chinese Leader’s Absence
abstract: If and when China’s presumptive new leader, Xi Jinping, re-emerges, he will do so in the midst of a contentious Communist Party preparing to shake up its leadership.

headline: Myanmar Releases Hundreds of Prisoners
abstract: The government said it had released 514 prisoners, many of whom were reported to have been political prisoners.

headline: Pay by Voice? So Long, Wallet
abstract: The Pay With Square service makes transactions easier than ever. If a retailer has your name and photo in its system, you only have to announce yourself to pay your bill.

headline: Jury Awards $1 Billion to Apple in Samsung Patent Case
abstract: The jury found that Samsung infringed upon a series of Apple patents on mobile devices, in a closely watched court case that could have broad implications for the industry.

headline: Retiring Envoy to Afghanistan Exhorts U.S to Heed Its Past
abstract: Ryan C. Crocker, the diplomat most linked to the invasions of Iraq and Afghanistan, says policy makers must learn from those wars as they consider military options for current crises.

headline: Judge Dismisses Suit by Londoners Wary of Olympic Air Defenses on Their Roof
abstract: The ruling endorsed the argument that air defense weapons in a residential area in London were necessary to ward off a terrorist strike.

headline: U.S. Reports That Piracy Off Africa Has Plunged
abstract: The United States Navy credited aggressive patrolling by international forces and increased vigilance by the shipping industry for a decrease in piracy in the waters around the Horn of Africa.

headline: Two Sudans Reach Deal on Fees for Oil Pipelines
abstract: A deal was reached in talks in Ethiopia, with pressure from the United States, on how much South Sudan, which has the oil, will pay Sudan, through which the export pipelines run.

headline: In Vietnam, Growing Fears of an Economic Meltdown
abstract: In Vietnam’s major cities, a once-booming property market has come crashing down, adding to an economic slowdown that is being compared to the 1997 Asian financial crisis.

headline: Facebook Shares Hit New Low as a Lockup Period Ends
abstract: Shares fell sharply amid fears that early investors eligible to offload their stocks would create a surplus on the market.

headline: Spanish Ire, Symbolized by a Carrot
abstract: Spanish politics make it harder for Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy to meet financial obligations to the rest of the euro zone. Consider the carrot rebellion.

headline: Gunmen Attack U.N. Vehicle in Pakistan, Wounding Polio Doctor
abstract: The attack was a further blow to the three-day polio vaccination drive, which had already been stymied in some parts of the country by Taliban threats.

headline: How the Center of the Earth Got a Little Off Kilter
abstract: At Ecuador’s Middle of the World park, tourists stand on a yellow line that is said to be precisely at Earth’s midpoint. Except that it is not. The Equator is hundreds of feet north.

headline: Meles Zenawi, Prime Minister of Ethiopia, Dies at 57
abstract: Mr. Meles oversaw substantial economic growth as prime minister and made Ethiopia a staunch American counterterrorism ally but drew criticism for harsh treatment of dissidents.

headline: Socialists in France Announce New Taxes
abstract: France’s new Socialist government announced billions of euros in new taxes and tax increases, designed to bring the country’s deficit down in a period of nearly stagnant growth.

headline: Europe Objects to Universal Acquisition of EMI
abstract: A so-called statement of objections that was sent to Universal spelled out concerns over the market power of the combined company.

headline: Iran: Top Nuclear Negotiator Calls Talks With Big Powers ‘Constructive’
abstract: Iran’s top negotiator in talks with the big powers over his country’s disputed uranium enrichment program called negotiations with his counterpart, “constructive and helpful.”

headline: Card Swipes in Church Make Giving Easier
abstract: Most religious institutions are better at collecting money than they used to be, by accepting donations via credit card or electronically pulling money from people’s bank accounts.

headline: Brazil’s Ex-President Is Back on Front Lines
abstract: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, the former president of Brazil, is winning over onetime rivals for his allies, and is anything but shy when it comes to blasting Europe’s handling of its debt crisis.

headline: Fears Rising, Spaniards Pull Out Their Cash and Get Out of Spain
abstract: While the situation in Spain is not as dire as that of Greece, some Spaniards are taking their euros, and sometimes themselves and their families, out of the country.

headline: Zambia: Chinese Supervisor Dies During Protest at Mine
abstract: Workers striking at a Chinese-owned coal mine killed a Chinese supervisor when they hit him with a coal trolley, officials of the mine workers’ union said Monday.

headline: Chinese Government Scientist Raises Doubt on Evidence in a Murder Case
abstract: The government scientist said testimony in the trial of Gu Kailai, the wife of a disgraced politician, did not show that Neil Heywood, a British businessman, was poisoned by cyanide.

headline: Berlusconi Magazine to Publish Duchess Photos
abstract: The images of Kate Middleton sunbathing topless first appeared in the French magazine Closer, which is also owned by former Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi’s Mondadori group.

headline: Pope’s Butler Indicted in Vatican Leak Case
abstract: Paolo Gabriele, the butler, is charged with aggravated theft and accused of taking and then leaking documents from the pope’s private apartment that raised allegations of corruption at the Vatican.

headline: Tajikistan: Armed Group Is Offered Amnesty in Exchange for Weapons
abstract: Some members of an armed group in the town of Khorog, which is on the border with Afghanistan, have surrendered their weapons in exchange for amnesty, officials said.

headline: To Sketch, to Draw, to Create, With No Pencil in Sight
abstract: Put away the sketchbook and pencil. Sketching has gone digital, and several apps make it easy.

headline: Support for the Euro Is Seen in Dutch Election Results
abstract: Dutch voters appeared to give Prime Minister Mark Rutte a narrow victory, which will bring a sigh of relief to European allies anxious about rising euro skepticism in the richer countries of the north.

headline: Price Data Suggest Specter of Deflation in China
abstract: Markets fell on Monday after reports of slowdowns in consumer and producer prices.

headline: Hungarians Stage a Fast Over Rules for Voters
abstract: The weeklong fast outside Parliament is the latest protest against the policies of Hungary’s prime minister, who has been accused of undermining the country’s young democracy.

headline: Terror Charges as London Olympics Near
abstract: British police officials insisted that the accusations were not related to the Olympic Games opening on July 27.

headline: Lawyers Seek the Release of a Christian Girl Charged With Blasphemy in Pakistan
abstract: The fate of Rimsha Masih, who is accused of burning an Islamic holy book, hung in the balance on Tuesday, as lawyers applied for her release from jail and an influential Muslim cleric offered his support.

headline: Rebels Announce Move of Headquarters From Turkey to ‘Liberated’ Syria Territory
abstract: The practical effect of a move to “liberated areas” of Syria by the main umbrella group for those fighting President Bashar al-Assad remains unclear, and the new location carries risks.

headline: Treasury Backs Plan for Standard Chartered Settlement
abstract: The prospective penalty would be smaller than the $340 million the British bank had to pay a New York State regulator to settle a money laundering case.

headline: Greek Premier Sees Hope, but Only if Europe Helps
abstract: In an interview, Prime Minister Antonis Samaras of Greece said there was “zero risk” that Greece will leave the euro, but warned of growing unrest in Europe.

headline: Syrian Fighting Intensifies in Battle for Control of Aleppo
abstract: Syrian rebels’ handling of pro-government militiamen drew criticism amid claims of new massacres by government forces.

headline: Paris Wants Smokers to Kick a Bad Habit: Tossing Butts in the Street
abstract: The city is installing plastic snuffers on public trash bins in an effort to cut down on cigarette waste in gutters and on sidewalks.

headline: ‘Living Wills’ for Too-Big-to-Fail Banks Are Released
abstract: Regulators released contingency plans for nine large banks in the event of a collapse, but skeptics say that failures unfold unpredictably.

headline: Afghan Finance Minister Under Scrutiny
abstract: Omar Zakhilwal, Afghanistan’s finance minister, has come under scrutiny for bank records that suggest he accepted sizable payments from businesses and individuals and transferred money to Canada.

headline: Russia Prods Syria’s President Assad With Message of Growing Impatience
abstract: The Syrian president was pressured to be more flexible about the future of his ravaged country, and to talk with his adversaries.

headline: In Pursuit of Nissan, a Jobs Lesson for the Tech Industry?
abstract: Executives have long said America can’t compete in building electronic devices. But the migration of carmaking from Japan is a case study in the most unlikely of transformations.

headline: Europe Tries to Ease Concerns Over Rescue Plan for Banks
abstract: The European Commission tried to calm some governments — notably Germany, Finland and the Netherlands — over recapitalizing ailing euro zone banks.

headline: Relief Crisis Grows as Refugees Stream Out of Syria
abstract: Two million Syrian citizens who desperately need help are not receiving it, according to international officials, and with thousands fleeing daily, the exodus now exceeds a quarter of a million.

headline: French Leader Hails Greeks for ‘Painful Efforts’ in Crisis
abstract: President François Hollande of France expressed his commitment Saturday to keep Greece in the euro zone, but he urged its new prime minister, Antonis Samaras, to go all out to solve the economic crisis.

headline: Tech and Media Elite Are Likely to Debate Piracy
abstract: Top technology and entertainment executives will gather in Sun Valley, Idaho, on Tuesday, the first time they have done so since the debate over two controversial antipiracy bills.

headline: Foxconn Factory in China Is Closed After Worker Riot
abstract: Foxconn Technology said on Monday that it had closed one of its large Chinese plants after police were called in to to break up a fight among factory employees.

headline: Series of Write-Downs Leads to a Loss at BP
abstract: Analysts were already disappointed in the performance of the oil company, which reported a $1.4 billion loss for the second quarter.

headline: Clashes Worsen Misery in Syria’s Biggest Cities
abstract: Battles between the Syrian military and rebels burst a main pipe that delivered drinking water to hundreds of thousands of residents of Aleppo, opposition groups said Saturday.

headline: Islamists in North Mali Stone Couple to Death
abstract: A local official said that they were executed in an insurgent-held town on accusations of having children outside of marriage.

headline: Attacks on 6 Banks Frustrate Customers
abstract: The cyberattacks, by a group claiming Middle Eastern ties, caused Internet blackouts and delays in online banking, and the banks did not explain clearly what was going on.

headline: Spreading the Faith Where Faith Itself Is Suspect
abstract: As the Roman Catholic Church tries to grow in China, it increasingly finds itself in conflict with the authorities.

headline: G.O.P. Shift Moves Center Far to Right
abstract: A look back at Richard Nixon’s stands on big government programs and new regulations underscores how much the political center has moved.

abstract: Ms. Brown, who wrote the best-selling book “Sex and the Single Girl” and was the longtime editor of Cosmopolitan, was widely credited with being the first to introduce frank discussions of sex into magazines for women.

abstract: Russia negotiated longer than any other major country to join the World Trade Organization because opponents felt the country had little to gain from membership.

abstract: The White House is girding itself for an extended period of turmoil that will test the security of American diplomatic missions and President Obama’s ability to shape the forces of change in the Arab world.

abstract: In Georgia, a university’s journalism department injects life and resources into local coverage, and a chronicler of police misconduct in Harlem says he has been punished for his work.

abstract: The observance of Ramadan by locals in Srinagar, summer capital of Jammu and Kashmir State.

headline: China Defers Death Penalty for Disgraced Official’s Wife
abstract: Gu Kailai, the wife of Bo Xilai, received a suspended death sentence for the poisoning death of a British business associate. In the Chinese legal system, such a sentence is often commuted to life in prison.

headline: Afghan President Moves to Reassure Allies After Security Ministers Are Dismissed
abstract: President Hamid Karzai said he respected Parliament’s decision to fire two senior security officials, but it was not clear how quickly he would replace them.

headline: Car Bomb Kills 12 in Yemen, but Targeted Minister Escapes Harm
abstract: A blast alongside a convoy of vehicles used by Yemen’s defense minister came one day after a top operative for Al Qaeda in the country was killed.

headline: After Violence in India, a Crackdown Online
abstract: Officials blame texting and Internet rumors for setting off a wave of ethnic violence, but others call the claims ridiculous and simplistic.

abstract: Renata Polverini, the president of the Lazio region, which includes Rome, resigned Monday in the wake of a political finance scandal that includes accusations of the misuse of public money.

headline: Peter Lougheed, Ex-Premier of Alberta, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Lougheed turned Alberta into a major player in oil and gas and a pioneer in the development of oil sands.

headline: Norway Mass Killer Gets the Maximum: 21 Years
abstract: Anders Behring Breivik, who admitted to killing 77 people, many of them children, will live in a three-cell suite. The relative leniency of his sentence is no anomaly.

abstract: For months, party elders and current senior officials have been negotiating quietly in Beijing to fill the seats of the party’s top governing bodies, the 25-member Politburo and its elite Standing Committee.

abstract: Maybe the way to start building a consensus about how much people should be taxed is to make the connection between the taxes people pay and the benefits they finance.

headline: U.S. Begins Packing Its Afghan War Gear for the Movers
abstract: As the Afghan war draws to a close, the American military has already began an immense logistical effort, spanning half the globe, to ship back its equipment.

abstract: Airports in St. Louis, Pittsburgh, Cincinnati and other secondary cities are having to address vacant terminals and hangars as they lose business to bigger destinations.

headline: Slovenia Encounters Debt Trouble and May Need Bailout
abstract: Five years after joining the euro zone, this alpine nation risks the dubious distinction of becoming the first ex-socialist country in the European Union to need a bailout.

headline: Rebels Are Said to Defeat Syrian Forces in Battle at Border
abstract: Syria’s civil war again spilled into border areas as rebels reportedly drove government troops from a northern frontier crossing.

headline: Russians Eagerly Participate in Medical Experiments, Despite Risks
abstract: Even though tests sometimes go awry, patients in Russia are eager to join drug trials because often they are the only way to receive modern medical care.

headline: Israeli Sharpens Call for United States to Set Iran Trigger
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu criticized the Obama administration for not setting clear “red lines” on Iran’s nuclear progress that would prompt the United States to undertake a military strike.

headline: Mexico: Attack Kills Four in Acapulco
abstract: The attack appeared to be the work of organized criminals, according to an official from the state prosecutor’s office.

headline: Coalition Soldiers Killed Were Shot in Company of Afghans
abstract: The killings heightened worries about how the coalition troops can protect themselves while working at close quarters with their Afghan counterparts.

headline: Two Americans Killed by Afghan Recruit
abstract: In a second “green on blue” attack, in the south, an Afghan security force member wounded two American soldiers, the latest in a spate of attacks by Afghan forces on their coalition counterparts.

headline: Taliban Kill at Least 8 Pakistani Soldiers in Ambush
abstract: Taliban fighters armed with rifles and rocket launchers launched an ambush early Wednesday in South Waziristan, near the Afghan border, military officials and Taliban commanders said.

headline: In Belarus Election, President’s Supporters Win Every Seat in Parliament
abstract: Voter turnout was reported to be 74 percent, despite calls for a boycott by two opposition parties. The election, as many in post-Soviet authoritarian states, was widely seen as rigged.

headline: Iran Nuclear Talks Are to Continue as Their Tone Heats Up
abstract: Discussions in Istanbul ended with no word of progress, but both sides said another meeting was planned.

headline: Euro’s Medicine May Be Making Greece’s Symptoms Worse
abstract: Many experts say that the austerity targets set for Greece were unrealistic from the start and that compliance itself has harmed its economy.

headline: New Director of BBC Is Named
abstract: George Entwistle, the head of the television division, will succeed Mark Thompson at a time when the network is struggling.

headline: Qantas in a Venture to Improve International Reach
abstract: A new 10-year partnership ended a previous alliance between the Australian carrier and British Airways, and aimed to reverse losses on Qantas’s international business.

headline: Ragtag Revolts in Parts of Afghanistan Repel Taliban
abstract: While distrusting the government, many villagers have also come to loathe the Taliban for their dictatorial cruelty and are fighting back.

headline: Greece Pressed to Resume Austerity Program
abstract: European officials expressed confidence that the country's new government would have the funds to meet a debt payment coming due in August.

headline: Drought Forces Reductions in U.S. Crop Forecasts
abstract: The United States slashed its estimate of the annual corn crop by 15.5 percent, to its lowest level since 1995, with the cost of processed food, animal feed and ethanol likely to rise.

headline: Dish Network Drops Home of ‘Mad Men’
abstract: In a dispute between the two companies, Dish asserted that AMC required the network to carry low-rated channels so that it could access popular shows like “Mad Men” and “The Walking Dead.”

headline: Cocaine’s Flow Is Unchecked in Venezuela
abstract: Venezuela’s government has trumpeted one major blow after another against drug traffickers, but a visit to its remote western plains shows that its claims are greatly overstated.

headline: Russia: 2 Police Officers Found Guilty in Police Brutality Case in Kazan
abstract: A regional court handed down the first guilty verdicts in a case that exposed the systematic torture of suspects in a police department in the capital of the Tatarstan Republic.

headline: To Smuggle More Drugs, Traffickers Go Under the Sea
abstract: American authorities have discovered models of a new drug-ferrying submarine capable of traveling, unseen from the surface, from Ecuador to Los Angeles.

headline: A Tablet to Rival the Leader
abstract: Google’s Nexus 7, a sleek, full-blown tablet with the latest version of Android 4.1, is playing Follow the Leader with Apple’s iPad, David Pogue says.

headline: Egypt, Hearing From Obama, Moves to Heal Rift From Protests
abstract: A blunt phone call from President Obama prompted Egyptian leaders to scramble Thursday to try to repair the country’s alliance with Washington.

headline: U.S. Accuses Hezbollah of Aiding Syria’s Crackdown
abstract: The United States said the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah has trained and advised government forces inside Syria and has helped to expel opposition fighters from within the country.

headline: DreamWorks Animation Plans Shanghai Entertainment District
abstract: The $3.1 billion Dream Center, a riverfront complex that is expected to cover six large city blocks, has ambitions to rival the Broadway theater district and the West End in London.

headline: Seoul Judge Surprises Tycoon With Prison Term
abstract: Kim Seung-youn was convicted of embezzlement in a case that drew new attention to public mistrust in South Korea of the judiciary.

headline: In Defense of the Power of Paper
abstract: Though surrounded by computer terminals, many office workers still have practical reasons for using pen and paper in their daily tasks.

headline: Medicare Bills Rise as Records Turn Electronic
abstract: The move to electronic health records may be adding billions of dollars to Medicare costs by enabling hospitals and physicians to bill more for the same services.

headline: In Conservative Japan Enclave, Antinuclear Candidate Gains Ground
abstract: Nearly a year and a half after Japan’s nuclear disaster, the election has evolved into an informal referendum on nuclear power’s place in the country’s future.

headline: 3 Georgians Accused of Trying to Stage Prison Videos
abstract: Georgian officials sought to take control of a week-old prison abuse scandal, arresting three activists from an opposition party.

headline: Ecuadoreans Close Ranks in Assange Standoff
abstract: While some Ecuadoreans have only a vague idea of who Julian Assange is, they are clear in their pleasure that their country stood up to Britain in the asylum dispute.

headline: A Lemon Grower Emphasizes Uses for Citrus Outside the Kitchen
abstract: Limoneira strives to promote other uses for its lemons, be it in beauty, health, lifestyle or cleaning.

headline: Sleepy Islands and a Smoldering Dispute
abstract: A clash over contested territory has set off worries about the effect on business ties between China and Japan.

headline: BlackBerrys Fail Overseas
abstract: Research in Motion said it had restored BlackBerry e-mail and other services in Europe, the Middle East and Africa after a technical problem.

headline: Iran’s President Says New Sanctions Are Toughest Yet
abstract: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad said the sanctions would not change Iran’s position in a nuclear dispute.

headline: Britain Adjusts Security Plans in Tense Countdown to the Olympics
abstract: The British government said it would deploy additional troops for security at the Games after a private firm said it could not train enough guards.

headline: In Singapore, Vitriol Against Chinese Newcomers
abstract: Tensions over immigration bedevil many nations, but what makes the clash here particularly striking is that most of Singapore’s population was already ethnic Chinese.

headline: Syria Seen as Trying to Roil Lebanon
abstract: The arrest of a former Lebanese government minister and the kidnapping of nearly 50 Syrians have contributed to a sense that Lebanon’s tenuous stability is waning.

headline: Spain’s Leader Plans New Austerity Steps as Miners Clash With Police
abstract: The measures from Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy, which include a rise in the national sales tax to 21 percent, are designed to reduce Spain’s budget deficit by $80 billion over the next two and a half years.

headline: 3 Men Arrested in Spain Are Suspected of Having Links to Al Qaeda
abstract: Spanish officials announced the arrest of three suspects who were believed to have been planning attacks in Spain and elsewhere.

headline: Egyptian Leader Adds Rivals of West to Syria Plan
abstract: Staking out a new leadership role for Egypt, President Mohamed Morsi is reaching out to Iran and other regional powers in an initiative to halt the violence in Syria.

headline: Apps That Recall a Time Before There Were Apps
abstract: Programs for your smartphone can recreate favorite computer games from your childhood, apply nostalgic effects to your photos and even turn your MP3 collection into a virtual stack of vinyl records.

headline: Inquiry Sees Chaos in Evacuations After Japan Tsunami
abstract: Children were left in areas with high radiation levels as computer-aided predictions on radioactive releases went unheeded, a government-sponsored inquiry reported Monday.

headline: Energy Policy in France Divides Governing Coalition of Socialists and Greens
abstract: Compromises on nuclear power have placed the Green Party’s leadership at odds with its base, and some are wondering if the Greens’ alliance with the Socialist Party can survive.

headline: Novatek May Break Russian Gas Export Monopoly
abstract: While Gazprom has long controlled Russia’s natural gas exports to Europe, the Kremlin is reportedly allowing Novatek to begin exporting gas to Germany, a shift that once seemed inconceivable.

headline: Reginald Bartholomew, Busy Diplomat, Dies at 76
abstract: Mr. Bartholomew, a senior American diplomat, negotiated for nuclear disarmament with the Soviet Union and survived a bomb attack while he was ambassador to Lebanon in 1984.

headline: China: Muslim Fasting Discouraged
abstract: Several local governments in the western region of Xinjiang have ordered Muslim restaurants to stay open during the holy month of Ramadan and are telling civil servants and students to continue to eat and drink during daylight hours.

headline: Assad Admits Difficulties, but Projects Confidence
abstract: In a television interview, President Bashar al-Assad gave a sober assessment of the resilience of the armed insurgency and the limits of a military hobbled by a stream of defections.

headline: Allies Rebuke Pakistan on Cross-Border Attacks
abstract: The American-led coalition bluntly rebutted a Pakistani official’s statement that allied forces had done little over all to stop Pakistan Taliban militants from attacking Pakistani forces from Afghanistan.

headline: Hard Work and Charity
abstract: Ms. Carter, who leads V & J Holding Companies, describes her challenge of the status quo in the franchise industry, and how she has given back to her hometown through her church.

headline: A Glimpse of Ramadan From the Kashmir Valley
abstract: The observance of Ramadan by locals in Srinagar, summer capital of Jammu and Kashmir State.

headline: A Naughty Word, and a Scolding From a Seatmate
abstract: I’m not much of a talker on flights. I figure people want to be left alone. But on one recent flight my seatmate was a girl about 6 years old; she was charming, but talked nonstop.

headline: Qatar Airways Delays Jet Delivery Over Wing Cracks
abstract: The airline said that delivery of its first Airbus A380 would be delayed by three months as it waited for modifications to the superjumbo’s wing following a cracking problem.

abstract: Greeks are increasingly angry over the prospect that public salaries and pensions will be sharply cut again in a last-ditch bid to secure a 31.5-billion-euro loan installment.

abstract: Janet Lavin Rapelye, the dean of admission at Princeton University, lends her expertise about college admissions by answering questions submitted by readers of The Choice.

headline: Daily Report: Apps and Web Sites for Car-Pooling
abstract: Ride-sharing and car-pooling have traditionally not been popular in the United States. But with advances in digital technology and social networking, a lot of barriers have been removed, and long-distance travelers as well as commuters are connecting on sites like Zimride.com, Ridejoy.com, Avego.com, Nuride.com, Rideshare.com and eRideShare.com.

headline: Money, Power, Politics and Corruption: U.S. vs. China

headline: Zuckerberg Acknowledges ‘Disappointing’ Wall Street

headline: Bets on European Bonds Paying Off for Funds

abstract: Thoma Bravo, a private equity firm based in Chicago, has agreed to buy Deltek, an enterprise software company, for $1.1 billion in cash.

headline: Citigroup’s Profit Down 12%, but Beats Estimates
abstract: The bank reported profit of $2.9 billion, or 95 cents a share, although its revenue fell to $18.6 billion.

abstract: Ivan Glasenberg, chief executive of the commodities trading company Glencore International, played down speculation that the company would pay a higher price for its proposed $30 billion takeover of the mining company Xstrata.

headline: Diamond to Forgo Up to $31 Million in Bonuses From Barclays
abstract: Robert E. Diamond Jr., the former chief executive of Barclays, will forgo deferred bonuses of up to $31 million, as the British lender looks to quell public anger over an interest rate-rigging scandal.

headline: Trading Loss at JPMorgan Will Result in Millions in Pay Givebacks
abstract: Ina Drew is one of four former officials of the bank who are to lose the equivalent of two years of compensation because of their involvement in the trading fiasco that has cost the bank at least $5.8 billion.

headline: Q&A: Turning Off an Annoying Safari Alert
abstract: Apple’s Safari browser repeatedly offers to save user names and passwords for Web sites — until the setting is turned off .

abstract: Sequence’s new offices are at 337 Broome Street at the Bowery, and it will start with about a dozen employees.

abstract: Illegal immigration, porous borders are root causes of the current problems in Assam, adviser says.

abstract: A high-protein diet is linked to heart risks, women seek an over-the-counter fix for libido, finding a missing Nook book and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Glencore’s Bid to Buy Xstrata Is Increased at the 11th Hour
abstract: Glencore International, the world’s biggest commodities-trading company, sweetened its offer for Xstrata in a last-minute bid to save the mega-merger.

headline: In Monza, a Race That Resembles the Season
abstract: Lewis Hamilton drove his McLaren Mercedes to a dominating victory at the Italian Grand Prix, and the race was full of other interesting plots and angles as well, which befits the current Formula One season.

headline: Why Did Britain’s Highest-Ranking Female Soldier Resign?
abstract: As roles for women in the armed forces increase with changes in the nature of today’s militaries, Britain’s highest-ranking female solder — tipped to become the country’s first female general — is bowing out.

abstract: Nearly half of American adults take prescription drugs, a new report finds.

abstract: The Texas-based engineering company has agreed to buy a rival, the Shaw Group, in a cash-and-stock deal worth $3 billion.

abstract: Wade Michael Page, the suspect in the Sunday shooting was a white supremacist who performed in a racist rock band.

headline: T-Mobile Offers a New Unlimited Data Plan
abstract: Unlimited data plans usually come with an asterisk – the speed at which you get the data slows to a crawl after you have used a certain amount of data. T-Mobile is reversing the trend, adding an unlimited plan without restraints, but there is a catch.

Simons, the billionaire hedge fund quant and onetime math professor. | The negotiations between Glencore and Xstrata are centering on the question of who will run the new company.

abstract: Heineken claimed victory in its fight to gain control of Asia Pacific Breweries on Friday, announcing a sweetened deal to buy the rights to the beer maker held by Fraser & Neave for about $4.5 billion.

abstract: How to succeed in college, clothing retailers open stores just for men, a phone that can take a dunking and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

It’s part of a broader push by the companies to use social media, competitive games and Big Brotherish data analysis to persuade customers to conserve.

But you probably haven’t heard much about Ken Segall, who worked for the ad agency responsible for Apple’s “Think Different” campaign. He has tales to tell.

They prefer to see foreign films that have a rosy view of the mainland and heroic Chinese actors — which could spell trouble for the upcoming “Iron Man 3″ and its evil comic-book fiend the Mandarin. Hollywood studios have already edited and rewritten some major films to please the censors.

abstract: The Romney campaign declined to comment either on whether S.B.A. appropriations would be squeezed or, more generally, on the agency’s place in Mr. Romney’s small-business agenda.

abstract: The move into Tal Shehab is the latest step in a sweeping military campaign seeking to wipe out the opposition and raises fears that tens of thousands of refugees who have been fleeing across the border may be cut off.

abstract: A Russian Air Force MiG-29 fighter jet crashed Thursday afternoon near Chita, a city in Eastern Siberia, slamming into a hill close to a local airport and killing the pilot.

abstract: Hanna Adams joined PJA Advertising and Marketing as an account supervisor. She had been an account supervisor at Hill Holliday, Boston, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

abstract: At least two Ugandan military helicopters, key assets in a push against militants in Somalia, “lost communication” somewhere in Kenyan airspace and may have crashed, officials said.

abstract: Tropical Storm Isaac unleashed heavy rain over Haiti on Friday, raising the threat of floods and mudslides that could worsen the misery of a nation still devastated from the 2010 earthquake.

abstract: Aruba Networks, a maker of components for mobile devices, surged 14 percent after reporting quarterly sales and profit that exceeded analysts’ estimates.

abstract: The attack on the base, where some of Pakistan’s nuclear weapons are thought to be stored, left nine people dead.

abstract: Britain has indicated that it will not let Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder, leave, so he is likely to stay in Ecuador’s London embassy.

abstract: The coalition strike killed more than 20 insurgents at a public execution in northeastern Afghanistan, Afghan officials said.

abstract: Gander Mountain is expanding its shoe offerings, a move it will promote with an elaborate campaign.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
abstract: Account assignments, executive appointments and miscellaneous news from advertising agencies.

abstract: World Trade Center Properties, which owned the twin towers, sued American and United Airlines in 2008 alleging negligence in the 2001 terrorist attacks.

headline: Spouse’s Consent Is Required to Change Retirement Account Beneficiary
abstract: Spousal consent guidelines can vary, so investors should know the specific requirements for their account.

abstract: The number of Syrians fleeing to neighboring countries for safety and aid is likely to exceed 700,000 by the end of the year, humanitarian agencies said.

abstract: Key areas are expanding far less than expected compared with the same period a year ago, although inflation has decreased dramatically.

abstract: Investigators said that a fan shaft inside the Boeing Dreamliner’s General Electric engine broke, expelling shards of hot metal and starting a fire on the ground.

abstract: The company, which is working on a series of projects to improve service, said it had added more phone and broadband subscribers.

abstract: Nuclear energy would help Britain reach its carbon-reduction goals, but concerns linger over costs and safety.

abstract: The company’s patents for its Nespresso coffee machine system do not prevent consumers from using other capsules, a regional court in Germany said.

headline: France: Unesco Awards Prize Financed by Dictator
abstract: Unesco on Tuesday awarded a prize for research in the life sciences made controversial because it was financed by the dictator of Equatorial Guinea, a tiny, repressive and impoverished state.

headline: Officials Turn Blind Eye as Religious Tensions Rise in Indonesia
abstract: In Indonesia, a country long considered a model of religious moderation, local religious leaders have pushed for more restrictions on different faiths and sects.

abstract: The Israeli defense minister, Ehud Barak, said on Monday that a terrorist attack that killed 15 Egyptian soldiers underscored a growing danger at the border between the two nations.

abstract: The prime minister has pledged to cut Spain’s deficit to 4.5 percent of gross domestic product from 6.3 percent this year.

headline: Turmoil Over Contentious Video Spreads
abstract: In Yemen, hundreds of protesters attacked the American Embassy, two days after assailants killed the American ambassador in Libya and crowds tried to overrun the embassy compound in Cairo.

abstract: Pranab Mukherjee, most recently the finance minister, was selected for the largely ceremonial post by an electoral college.

abstract: Aegis Group, London, acquired the search and related digital marketing assets of WGarden, a French provider of search services. WGarden will become part of the iProspect unit of Aegis.

abstract: A spokesman for the Russian Academy of Sciences told the Interfax news agency that Raúl Castro wanted to view the Lenin Mausoleum but not the embalming laboratory affiliated with it.

abstract: Producer prices rose 0.1 percent as food costs increased.

abstract: Egypt’s next government will include representation of different segments of society, the official Middle East News Agency said.

abstract: Brig. Gen. Manaf Tlass, the former commander of an elite Republican Guard unit in Syria, made an announcement on television.

abstract: Account assignments, executive appointments and miscellaneous news from advertising agencies.

headline: Condé Nast Traveler Sees the World in Anniversary Style
abstract: The magazine has signed Chase Card Services and United Airlines to sponsor the promotion selling discounted travel packages.

headline: Spotlighting Women Who Lead
abstract: Advertising Age’s first ever list of the 100 most influential women in the industry coincides with the 100th anniversary of a trade organization that supports women in advertising.

abstract: The executions of at least nine Pashtuns in Afghanistan have been linked to the killings of two Hazaras, raising fears of continued revenge killings.

abstract: A group of doctors and public health officials urged the government to curtail the use of prescription painkillers by changing labeling directions on how physicians should prescribe them.

abstract: To meet online competition, shopping malls are signing tenants that offer dining, hairstyling, craft-making and other things the Internet can’t provide.

abstract: The uncle of Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, met on Friday in Beijing with President Hu Jintao and Premier Wen Jiabao of China.

abstract: A Senate committee passed a bill in favor of a tax break for the wind industry on a bipartisan vote on Thursday, helped by Republicans from states where wind power is common.

abstract: Helping to process the staggering amount of Internet activity that occurs, data centers waste vast amounts of energy, belying the information industry’s image of environmental friendliness.

abstract: Economic conditions have many workers worried that their company retirement plans will not provide enough income, but top executives could actually benefit from those conditions.

abstract: Stefano Pilati, who worked at Saint Laurent in Paris for eight years before being let go after mixed reviews, will join Zegna as creative director, where his mission will include building up the Agnona women's brand.

headline: Soccer Star Acquitted in British Trial Over Racial Slur
abstract: John Terry was acquitted of racially abusing an opposing player, Anton Ferdinand, in an unusual case that provided a vivid window into what happens on the field in British Premier League soccer games.

headline: Wealth Rises in Mongolia, as Does Worry
abstract: Development of its mining sector has brought new wealth to this remote, landlocked country, but also concerns about corruption and materialism.

abstract: Google’s proposal seeks to address European concerns that it might have abused its dominance in Internet search by promoting its own businesses at the expense of rivals.

headline: On a Bleak Holiday, Assad Makes a Display of Piety
abstract: President Bashar al-Assad’s appearance seemed to be an attempt at normalcy during Id al-Fitr, a three-day holiday after Ramadan, but it renewed doubts about the strength and confidence of the Syrian government.

headline: For Putin, Report Says, State Perks Pile High
abstract: In a new report, Russian opposition leaders describe the presidential perks enjoyed by Vladimir V. Putin, including palaces, a fleet of jets and droves of luxury cars.

abstract: A French court will open a homicide investigation into the 2004 death of the former Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, French news media reported Tuesday.

abstract: A series of earthquakes in southwest China shook two rural provinces populated by some of the country’s poorest people, damaging 20,000 homes, an official said.

abstract: Nearly 16 months after first pledging to help Egypt’s failing economy, the Obama administration is nearing an agreement with the country’s new government to relieve $1 billion of its debt.

headline: Sales at Wal-Mart, Though Still Rising, Suggest Wary Shoppers

abstract: The Swiss bank, one of more than a dozen being investigated for manipulating interest rates, has a trail of transgressions that makes it stand out from other banks.

abstract: The move appeared designed to reinforce China’s claims over the South China Sea a week after a meeting of foreign ministers of the Association of South East Asian Nations.

abstract: The opposition Liberal Democrats scuttled a budget bill, dealing a blow to the ruling Democratic Party and darkening Japan’s economic outlook.

abstract: The fall of the Syrian government would present Israel with a number of problems, including concerns about chemical weapons and the Golan Heights.

abstract: Opposition to proposals intended to prevent another financial panic puzzled the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

abstract: China drove home its opposition to Japanese control of a contested group of islands Tuesday, with angry protests in dozens of cities and a warning from its defense minister that “further actions” were possible.

abstract: Supporters say that the charges against Taisiya Osipova, who was convicted for possessing and selling heroin, were fabricated in retaliation for her work in opposition to Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin.

abstract: The United Nations refugee agency said that 10,200 Syrians had crossed into Jordan last week, and Syrian activists reported deadly government airstrikes in Idlib, near Turkey.

abstract: Supermarkets are mining the data from their loyalty card programs to adjust prices for and make marketing offers to individual customers.

abstract: Army shellings and shootings raged in at least three insurgency hot spots on Tuesday as Syria, backed by Russia, rejected warnings by President Obama about possible intervention.

abstract: New measures intensify existing efforts to choke off Iran’s oil and shipping revenue. Officials said the measures were not tied to Mitt Romney’s suggestion of a tougher line on Iran.

abstract: Sheik Mahdi al-Sumaidaie was known for urging extremists within his own sect to work with the Shiite-led government.

abstract: Under private equity ownership, HCA made an aggressive push for more revenue that sometimes led to conflicts with doctors and nurses over patient care.

abstract: The encampment outside a bank had been set up in October and was tolerated by the police until Monday, when they dismantled tents after complaints of a rat infestation.

abstract: President Bashar al-Assad’s forces fired on areas in and around Aleppo and the authorities reported two bomb attacks in Damascus.

abstract: The apparent rise of Islamic militancy could have far-ranging effects as the Kremlin looks for ways to promote moderate Islam and quash radical movements at home and abroad.

abstract: The Security Council vote to impose sanctions on the Syrian government was held amid rising violence and intensifying pressure on the United Nations to take action.

headline: British Regulator Declares BSkyB ‘Fit and Proper’
abstract: The announcement about Britain’s biggest satellite pay-TV group, British Sky Broadcasting, offered a victory for its largest shareholder, Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation.

abstract: A former sushi chef for the ruling Kim family, who fled North Korea for his native Japan in 2001 and wrote a tell-all book, was recently welcomed back for a two-week visit.

abstract: Deputies of the lead negotiators for Iran and the group of six nations in the Iranian nuclear dispute will meet in Turkey on July 24.

abstract: A girl was jailed after being accused of burning a religious textbook used to teach the Koran to children.

abstract: Along with the many funerals of the war in Syria, there are guilt-ridden weddings, and births, with new arrivals sometimes taking on the names of the departed.

headline: Colombia Will Restart Peace Process With FARC
abstract: President Juan Manuel Santos and the leader of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia said that the two sides would soon sit down to a new phase of peace talks.

abstract: Sleep next to heaps of laundry; eat ham out of the package; work till 3 in the morning. Such is life at “hacker hostels,” where young digerati network and keep their expenses down.

abstract: Mark Stadnyk is suing the United States government, aiming to block a patent law that he says is a triumph of corporate lobbying that will hurt lone inventors like him.

abstract: President Obama on Tuesday rejected an appeal by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to spell out a specific “red line” that Iran could not cross in its nuclear program.

abstract: Mariano Rajoy said that Spain could meet the financial obligations of its troubled regions, despite word from Valencia that it would require more rescue money than it requested in July.

abstract: An accounting charge related to Microsoft’s acquisition of an online advertising business led to a rare quarterly loss for the software giant. Revenue from Windows declined.

abstract: Some parents help their adult children financially, while others cannot or do not — and that often unspoken distinction among families can determine who gets ahead.

abstract: Court documents cast doubt on the independence of Moody’s and Standard & Poor’s in grading a deal involving a British debt issuer, Cheyne Finance, that went bad in 2007.

abstract: Mr. Gligoric was considered one of the greatest players of the 20th century and pioneered several systems of moves, but he never won the chance to compete for the world championship.

abstract: An intentional detonation of a 550-pound World War II bomb found in Munich set off fires late Tuesday that damaged a shop and nearby apartment buildings.

abstract: Nakoula Basseley Nakoula, one of the men behind the anti-Muslim film trailer that has sparked violent protests, was taken in for questioning by federal probation officers.

abstract: The Congressional Budget Office forecast that the economic recovery would continue — unless Congress takes no action to stave off tax increases and automatic budget cuts due.

abstract: President Mohamed Morsi’s decree to investigate the killing of protesters before and during the uprising appeared to be a challenge to the authority of Egypt’s security services.

abstract: There is no shortage of companies trying to dominate the nascent mobile payment industry, but consumers have yet to be won over.

headline: Life With Syria’s Rebels in a Cold and Cunning War
abstract: A rebel group presents a cross-section of a nation in upheaval – an accountant, real estate agent, farmers and laborers who have taken up arms believing their time has come.

headline: Russia: Parliament Ratifies Adoption Pact With U.S.
abstract: Parliament on Tuesday ratified an agreement with the United States on adoptions.

headline: Egypt’s Islamist Leaders Accused of Stifling Media
abstract: Facing strident criticism, President Mohamed Morsi’s government has suspended a satellite television channel, confiscated copies of a newspaper and censored columnists in a state newspaper.

headline: Last Somali Militant Bastion Falls, Kenya Claims
abstract: The capture of the port town of Kismayu, if confirmed, would spell an end to the Shabab’s ability to control large tracts of territory and the start of a guerrilla phase of fighting.

headline: A Young Syrian’s Evolution From a Carefree Tour Guide to a Revolutionary
abstract: A Bedouin man has struggled with uncertainty over whether joining a revolt was life’s proudest moment or its ruin — or both.

headline: Google Struggles to Unseat Amazon as the Web’s Most Popular Mall
abstract: As it inches into e-commerce, Google is now charging retailers to appear on its site, a move it says will improve product listings.

headline: German at European Central Bank at Odds With Country’s Policy Makers
abstract: The top German official at the European Central Bank defended its plans to intervene in bond markets as a way of lowering borrowing costs for business.

headline: China’s Growth Rate Slowed in the 2nd Quarter
abstract: The slowdown added to worries about the ability of the world’s second-largest economy to offset low growth elsewhere.

headline: South America Sees Drug Path to Legalization
abstract: Leaders are considering more permissive policies, such as the legalization and regulation of drug use and even drug transport, as a way to fight the spread of drug-related violence.

headline: In Lebanon, Pope Laments Strife in Syria, Where the War Rages On
abstract: On the final day of his trip to Lebanon, Pope Benedict XVI said a prayer for the victims of the conflict in Syria and appealed to the region and the world to find a solution.

headline: Equity Firms Like Bain Are Depicted as Colluding
abstract: Heavily redacted documents showed top private equity firms agreeing among themselves on which would bid on takeover targets.

headline: Prosecutor Returns Mubarak to Prison
abstract: Hosni Mubarak, Egypt’s former president, was abruptly moved from the comfort of a military hospital back to prison on Monday after a public prosecutor ruled that he was fit to serve his time behind bars.

headline: In Prosecutors, Debt Collectors Find a Partner
abstract: In exchange for a fee, district attorneys’ offices have been allowing debt collectors to use their letterhead when going after people behind on their bills.

headline: Expect Fewer Seats, Even for Overseas Flights
abstract: Airlines will probably continue to cut domestic capacity, especially in small markets, and will depend more on foreign partners.

headline: Crime Wave Engulfs Syria as Its Cities Reel From War
abstract: Even in neighborhoods where skirmishes are rare, Syrians say that thieves prey on the weak, and police stations no longer function because the officers have run away.

headline: Not Every Bad Day Needs to End With Ice Cream
abstract: Unilever makes childhood events a part of its new campaign for Ragu pasta sauce.

headline: Miriam Ben-Porat, Israeli Judge and Civic Watchdog, Dies at 94
abstract: Mrs. Ben-Porat was the first woman to serve as a justice on Israel’s Supreme Court and to hold the post of state comptroller.

headline: New Russian Jet Garners Orders Despite Crash
abstract: Sukhoi, which makes the Superjet 100, said it expected 40 new orders for the passenger plane even after the crash of a demonstration model in May.

headline: His First Rule of Business: Don’t Hope
abstract: Ben Lerer of the Thrillist Media Group never wants his employees to rely on luck in their work.

headline: North Korea Experts Can See a Lot in a Hemline
abstract: Analysts are looking at outward signs of a cultural thaw in North Korea, including shorter skirts and high heels, for clues to the thinking of its new leader.

headline: Somalia: Blasts Kill at Least 14
abstract: Two suicide bombers set off explosives on Thursday in a Mogadishu cafe frequented by Somali journalists and civil servants, killing at least 14 people and wounding 20, according to news reports.

headline: A Bruised Iceland Heals Amid Europe’s Malaise
abstract: While much of Europe is struggling to pull itself out of the recessionary swamp, Iceland’s economy is expected to grow by 2.4 percent this year.

headline: A French Shift on Africa Strips a Dictator’s Son of His Treasures
abstract: The seizure of a multimillion-dollar property owned by the son of the president of Equatorial Guinea underscores how France is changing its relationship with Africa.

headline: Small Trial Hints Drug Can Slow Alzheimer’s
abstract: Some Alzheimer’s patients who used the therapy, already approved for immune disorders, showed no worsening of symptoms for three years.

headline: Germany and Italy to Meet on Euro Crisis
abstract: Prime Minister Mario Monti of Italy is hoping to persuade his European partners to let the European Central Bank buy more government debt to help keep borrowing costs lower.

headline: Canada Closes Tehran Embassy and Orders Iran Envoys to Leave
abstract: Calling Iran “the most significant threat to global peace and security in the world today,” Canada’s foreign affairs minister said his government had cut all diplomatic ties with the country.

headline: Britain: Charges Over Heiress’s Death
abstract: Hans Kristian Rausing, an heir to his family’s multibillion-dollar cardboard packaging fortune, was charged Wednesday with “preventing the decent and lawful burial” of his wife, whose severely decomposed body was found in their opulent London house last week.

headline: Asian Leaders at Regional Meeting Fail to Resolve Disputes Over South China Sea
abstract: The influence of China hung over the deliberations at the meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, which Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton attended.

headline: NBC Unpacks Trove of Data From Olympics
abstract: Studies of more than 50,000 people who watched the Games depict vast shifts in how people watch television, especially with second devices like tablets or smartphones.

headline: Syrian Rebels Said to Be Holding Elite Fighters From Iran
abstract: American officials said they had evidence that hostages taken by Syrian rebels were members of Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps, not pilgrims as described by the government in Tehran.

headline: Letting the Cloud Watch Over the Farm
abstract: Cloud computing and other Internet services are coming to agriculture, allowing farmers to keep better track of their crops, livestock and expenses.

headline: Apple Officials Said to Consider Stake in Twitter
abstract: Apple, which has stumbled in its efforts to get into social media, has talked with Twitter in recent months about making a strategic investment in it, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Passionate on Two Topics: Wine and India
abstract: Dini Rao is head curator and chief merchandise officer for Lot18, an online wine site. She enjoys chatting with seatmates about her favorite subjects.

headline: Disruptions: Next Step for Technology Is Becoming the Background
abstract: From the printing press to the Google glasses, the earliest lumbering efforts in technology morph over time into streamlined, unnoticed tools of daily life, writes Nick Bilton.

headline: Where Have You Parked Your Short-Term Savings?
abstract: This week’s Your Money column looks at where savers with short-term savings goals can park their cash.

headline: Peugeot in Talks to Sell Logistics Business
abstract: A deal would help PSA Peugeot Citroën of France endure declining sales in Europe while bolstering Russian Railways’ links between Europe and Asia.

headline: Tips for Living on a College Student Budget
abstract: The author, who was raised in India, offers money management tips for international students who plan to study in the United States.

headline: New Fraud Inquiry as JPMorgan’s Loss Mounts
abstract: Amid a swirl of questions about a multibillion-dollar trading loss, JPMorgan said Friday that it would be forced to restate its first-quarter results, indicating that its traders may have intentionally been trying to conceal the extent of the red ink on the disastrous credit bet.

headline: India Lets in Wal-Mart, With Conditions
abstract: The government opens up India’s retail sector, but asks for sizable investment.

headline: Q&A: Checking Android App Permissions
abstract: Android apps list their permissions on both the device and on the Web.

headline: Business Day Live: Drought Disrupts Everyday Tasks in Rural Midwest
abstract: For farmers, drought becomes a way of life. | Americans near retirement suffer big income losses. | James B. Stewart discusses Mitt Romney’s foreign tax credit.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Twitter Founders’ Trifecta and Thoughts on the iPad Mini
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Thursday’s selection includes a third online publishing tool from the founders of Twitter and Blogger and musings on the possible design of the iPad Mini.

headline: A Glimpse of Ramadan From the Kashmir Valley
abstract: The observance of Ramadan by locals in Srinagar, summer capital of Jammu and Kashmir State.
